characters: L.B. GROVE, WARDEN STATE PENITENTIARY NORTON, NEV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT. The sun, spinning up from behind the dark rim eastern hills, is bleaching the cloudless, morning sky. T is volcanic country, barren, desolate, forbidding. There no sign of life, no sound. Then on a distant hill, a man  appears, to be followed by two others. They walk steadily forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT. A dry watercourse threads its way through the in the treeless hills. The sun is not high enough as yet drive night from the canyon. A man appears around a bend; another and still another. They are McCall, Peters and Le clad in prison clothes, hatless, their heads closely crop As Lednov's face comes into a closeup,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT - DOWN ANGLE. A narrow valley lies below. Throu it runs a cottonwood-bordered stream. Smoke curls up out the trees. Horses graze in a small meadow near the creek. From O.O. comes the SOUND of heavy boots crunching across the dry, eroded earth. The three men file past camera to  stop in the immediate F.g. and look down into the valley. They exchange glances and start down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT - ANGLED THROUGH willows. A bearded man, Cal  Forster, and two young fellows in their late teens squat  beside a campfire eating breakfast. O.s. there is the SOU of movement. Lednov moves cautiously into the scene. He h a revolver in his hand. Forster turns toward camera and fear comes into his  expression. Lednov fires. Forster crumples near the fire. The two boys jump to their feet and reach for rifles. Led fires again and again. McCall and Peters come into the sc both firing revolvers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED SHOT - ANGLED ACROSS campfire. On the fire smoulders prison clothes the convicts had worn. Smoke spirals up. I the B.B. Lednov, Peters and McCall, now wearing the cloth of the three Forsters, saddle the horses. CAMERA PANS ARO and ANGLES DOWN. The bodies of Forster and his sons, now  clad in underwear are sprawled by the fire. Forster's arm lies close to the smouldering clothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. LONG SHOT. Smoke climbs above the trees. Into the  clearing ride the three convicts, to cross it and move  westward. They disappear over the hill. A dust cloud mark their passage. CAMERA HOLDS ON the scene and over the sho comes the MAIN TITLE CARD:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT. A buckboard drawn by two horses comes along th road. Graham, a middle-aged rancher, is driving. As the h trot forward and dust rises above the road, the NEXT TITL CARD is shown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT - DOWN ANGLE. Graham's buckboard moves down the road toward the clearing, as the TITLE CARDS follow and  change. When the buckboard reaches the creek, the LAST TI CARD is ended.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT. Graham drives the horses through the creek and into the meadow. Through the trees the Forster camp can b seen. Graham glances over, then suddenly pulls on the rei As the horses stop, he twists the reins around the whip s grabs his rifle from under the seat, leaps out and hurrie forward toward the camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT. Graham hurries through the trees to stop in ho near the dead men. Then very slowly he moves forward to t smouldering fire. Stooping he lifts Forster's arm away fr the fire, then picks up one of the prison coats and looks it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. LONG SHOT. The surrounding hills are covered with sc pinon pine and mesquite. Graham's buckboard, moving slowl up a hill, passes camera, which PANS WITH it. In the bed, covered by a tarp, are the three bodies. The narrow, one- road climbs easily up the gentle hill. Beyond, a dust clo rises. As Graham's buckboard nears the crest, a surrey ap and starts down. Graham pulls his team into the bank, try to make room for the surrey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are four women in the two-seated surrey, which is  heavily loaded with trunks, hatboxes, etc. Mary Wells, th loveliest of the four, is driving. She is more poised, mo self-assured than the others. Her clothes, though a trifl showy, are attractive. She wears a large spectacular hat. Helen Carter, showier, harder and more cynical, sits besi her. In the seat behind are Marcia Paine, placid, younger looking than her years, and Elaine Ross, a striking blond with a pale haunted face. Elaine is obviously ill. Mary i riding the brake and holding the team back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOOTING PAST Graham.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (annoyed) What in thunderation -- (calling) Wait a minute -- stop --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He jerks on the reins and tries to make room for the surr A steep bank is on camera left. On camera right, the road drops off into a gulley. As the surrey comes up Mary rein the team in. The women all look frightened. Graham, tryin to force his team to pull the vehicle up the bank, is too occupied to recognize the women at once. Having made just enough room for the surrey, he turns and looks at the wom

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right -- (then surprised) What are you girls doin' way out  here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary looks ahead at the narrow road and the canyon to her left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until you came along we were going  to Sonora.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you know about that. Did you  sell your place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dryly) Not exactly. They decided gambling  and dancing were bad for people. (pointing) Can I make it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Depends on how good you drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a little out of practice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham jumps over the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: SURREY
dialogues.text: Graham reaches the surrey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cheerfully) Slide over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting up) I'm slidin' all the way over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She climbs out. Marcia looks at the narrow space ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising) So am I. Come on Elaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine leans back against the cushions and shakes her hea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flat) What's the difference if we fall in  the canyon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't talk like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen is out on the road now. Mary has moved over and Gra picks up the reins. Marcia gives up and jumps out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothin' to it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He releases the brake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- once you know how. Trouble is,  never was a woman knew how to handle  a team. Shouldn't let 'em loose on  the roads. No disrespect meant, Miss  Wells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary isn't listening. She is looking at the road. Elaine  closes her eyes. Helen and Marcia scurry back out of the  way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adroitly he drives the surrey past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: featuring buckboard. Helen and Marcia start along the roa past the buckboard. Helen stops and looks at its cargo in horror. She grabs Marcia's arm. The girls look at each ot and hurry after the surrey which has stopped below the  buckboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on surrey. Graham jumps out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you are. Now take it easy and  you'll be all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr. Graham.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen and Marcia hurry up. Marcia motions back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aghast) There's -- dead men -- in your wagon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. You had me so busy I  forgot -- (worried) Come to think of it you better turn  around and drive right back to Aspen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The women exchange glances. Elaine is sitting up, her eye open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were murdered. I found the bodies  on Alder Crick, northeast of here.  Like I said if I was you, I'd go  back, because the men who killed  them might be on this road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly) Back to what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, back to Aspen, where you came  from.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Mary speaks, Helen pushes Marcia into the surrey and c up beside Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aspen doesn't want us Mr. Graham.  They threw us out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (distressed) They shouldn't have done that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We tried to point that out. But there  were some pretty nosey citizens who  wouldn't listen to reason. They said  Aspen had outgrown us. It's all right  to play poker in your own home but  not in a saloon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sadly) I knew something would happen when  they started puttin' up fences and  passin' laws.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary unwraps the reins from the whipstock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye and thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like to see you go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary releases the brake and the surrey starts rolling for

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that's the way it is. The live  ones go out and the dead ones come  in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The surrey starts down the hill. Graham looks after it, t turns to go back to the buckboard, CAMERA PANNING WITH hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The town lies in a lush green valley. It is surrounded by meadowland and shaded by cottonwoods, alders and aspen. I the F.g. Graham's buckboard moves fast down hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT. In the F.g. a smallish crowd, mostly men and  children idle in the street in front of Mary Wells' Gambl and Dance Hall. The wooden sidewalk is cluttered with tho articles belonging to the women that were too bulky to ge into the surrey. Several women stand on the porch supervi the locking up of the place and the removal of the sign o Mary Wells' name on it. Graham's buckboard rounds a corne at a fast trot. He slows the team to let the people get o of the way.

dialogues.speaker: BUCKBOARD
dialogues.text: The team has slowed to a walk. The people give their atte to the buckboard. A boy clambers up over the tailboard, s the cargo and jumps off with a frightened yell. The crowd turns from the dance hall and follows the buckboard leavi the women and their pious male assistants on the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. FULL SHOT - ANGLED to include blacksmith shop across the street. Far down the street comes Graham's buckboard  followed by the small crowd. The sheriff's office is a on story wooden structure. Next to it is the general store. front of the blacksmith shop stands a wagon with one whee off. In the corral alongside are eleven blooded mares. Cl Phillips, his brother Steve and the blacksmith are inside the shop. Clay's saddle horse is tethered to the hitching rail beside two harnessed work horses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLED to include sheriff's office. The blacksmith, Sam E an elderly bent man in a leather apron stands at the forg in which he is heating the rim from the big wheel which l on the table nearby. Clay, a long-legged wrangler in clea but faded work clothes stands near the forge pumping the  bellows and watching his brother, a freckled kid of sixte trying to roll a cigarette. Steve has progressed to the m difficult step, that of licking and sealing the paper. Cl reaches over and takes it from him. He puts the skinny  cylinder in his mouth and Steve lights it for him. The fi third of the cigarette burns with one quick flare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How does she draw?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little hot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam lifts the rim to the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to get out of here before  noon, maybe you should lend me a  hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay, the cigarette dangling from his lips, moves over to the table, picks up a hammer and helps Sam hammer the rim the wheel. Steve stands watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rate you're goin', we'll be here  until winter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Together they lift the wheel and plunge it into the tub o water. Steam rises to fill the blackened shed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amiably grumbling) Account of you, I miss out on the  only excitement Aspen's had for  months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're too old to watch such goin's  on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm too young.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay and Sam spin the wheel in the tub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see no sense to makin' people  leave town if they don't want to  leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't either -- when people are  that good-lookin'. Maybe that's why --  they were too good-lookin'. (philosophically) But there'll be others along to take  their place after a while when this  quiets down. And everything will be  fine until some busybody starts  stirring up trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mildly) Don't you ever run down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Steve) Some people just have to run other  people's lives. Now take Clay. You  want to amble up the street and see  the fun and what does he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (good-natured) You stick to your blacksmithin' and  let me take care of Steve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From O.s. comes the SOUND of the approaching buckboard an crowd. Steve hears the noise and moves to the front of th shed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. FULL SHOT - Steve's angle. Graham pulls his buckboar up, jumps out and hurries into the sheriff's office. Some kids run up to stand on the porch chattering excitedly.  Members of the crowd straggle up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLED PAST Steve. Clay comes up to stand beside Steve. S joins them. Steve looks up at Clay hopefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll both take a look. Anything's  better than listenin' to Sam. (to Sam) Don't forget to shoe the mule.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay and Steve exit. Sam looks after them, shrugs disgust and goes back to the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT - featuring buckboard. The crowd around the wag stands in shocked silence looking at the bodies under the tarp. Clay and steve come up, glance in the buckboard and then at each other. Clay speaks to a man near him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't know. Graham brought 'em in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sheriff calls from O.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay, come up here a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff Gardner, who has seen Clay through the window, co out of his office on to the porch followed by Jeb Graham a young deputy. In his hand Gardner holds the burned pris jacket. Clay goes up the steps to the porch. Steve follow to the foot of the steps to stand watching. The crowd aro the wagon gives its attention to the men on the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gardner is neatly dressed with his star hidden under his  coat. His deputy wears jeans, shirt, and leather jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello Graham -- Joe -- Mr. Gardner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham's got something to tell you  might interest you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (motioning toward  wagon) Cal Forster and his sons. Somebody  killed 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pauses to let that sink in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know that cottonwood grove on  Alder Crick? They must have been  eatin' breakfast the way it looked,  sittin' by the fire eatin' breakfast  and when I got there nothin' but  them lyin' dead in their underdrawers.  No horses or guns or grub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shocked) Forster never did anyone any harm. (puzzled) But what's that got to do with me? I  came into town from the south.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gardner holds out the burned jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was smoulderin' on the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay moves over to glance down at the jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still don't see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From his pocket, Gardner takes several communications, th through them and passes one over. It is a telegram, of th period.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got it day before yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay reads it.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF GARDNER
dialogues.text: BE ADVISED OF ESCAPE OF LEDNOV, PETERS AND McCALL CONVICT

dialogues.speaker: L.B. GROVE, WARDEN STATE PENITENTIARY NORTON, NEV.
dialogues.text: BACK TO SCENE. Clay hands the telegram back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now are you interested?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should be. Maybe Lednov heard  about that Sonora ranch of yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to look for him. Want to  come along?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got eleven horses to get over  the mountains before snow catches me  and covers the feed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dryly) And that's more important than finding  Lednov?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like you said, maybe he knows where  my ranch is. If he does, he'll be  waiting on the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns toward the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with irony) I'll drop the sheriff in Sonora a  line to sort of look around for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay speaks over his shoulder as he goes down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Clay starts away, Steve follows him. Clay doesn't cros to the blacksmith shop. He goes along the sidewalk toward the general store. Steve hurries to catch up with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVING SHOT. Clay, deep in thought, seems unaware of his  brother at his side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's Lednov?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man I used to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk in silence to the General store and Clay goes u the steps and across the porch. Steve follows close behin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The store is a typical general store of the period, selli everything from buggies to baby clothes. In one corner is the postoffice. The storekeeper, Hayes, is unpacking a ca of canned goods, stacking the cans on the shelf. Clay,  followed by Steve, enters. Hayes glances over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay crosses to the shelf where the rifle and shotgun she are kept and takes down a half dozen boxes of 30 30  cartridges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget somethin', Clay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shells. How much for six boxes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six times six bits. But wait until I  finish this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Besides Clay, Steve is inspecting a rack of guns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might tell a fellow things,  'specially if the fellow's your  brother, seems to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve picks up a rifle, puts it to his shoulder and squin along the barrel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like why you're buyin' a whole slew  of 30 30 shells all of a sudden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to run short.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never said this Lednov's name  before, that I can remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No call to. That jail looked pretty  solid to me. (pointing to rifle) How's she feel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls the hammer back and snaps the trigger. Hayes com across and takes the gun from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know bettern' to do that, Steve.  Unless you're figurin' on buyin' it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One he's got, more his size.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's leaded up and anyway a 22's  no good for real huntin'. You shoot  a man with a 22 and where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The thing to do is stick to rabbits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands Hayes some money for the shells. Hayes crosses t another part of the store to get change. Clay and Steve, has picked up the rifle again, move over to the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was he in jail for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure worry that bone. He killed  a fellow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a fight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other fellow wasn't even lookin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is an awful nice gun. (sighting it) Certainly come in handy when there's  men around who shoot people that  aren't lookin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay grins. Hayes comes up with the change. Clay takes ou some bills and gives them to the storekeeper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (points to rifle) I may as well buy it for him.  Otherwise he'll be crying all the  way over the hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve's expression shows his gratitude and delight. He co up with banter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must be plenty worried about  Lednov sneakin' up on us. (hopefully) Think he will?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the ranch maybe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe at the ranch. Maybe sooner  than that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (annoyed) Do you have to be so close-mouthed?  I'm your brother. And I'm ridin'  with you. Remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) All right. I'll tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts one of the boxes of shells on the end of the coun

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's say this is the penitentiary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches down into one of the barrels in front of the  counter. The barrels are filled with beans, nails, dried  apples, hardtack, etc. Clay takes a handful of beans and  makes a trail ending in a little pile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's Alder Crick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts another box of shells on the other side of the  counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And here we are in Aspen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He runs a trail of beans away from "Aspen" toward the end the counter. He runs another trail from "Alder Crick" to  cross the Aspen trail. He puts another box of shells on t far end of the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Sonora.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches down without looking and brings up a hardtack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: motioning) Lednov gets out of jail  and comes along here to Alder Crick.  Then goes along here toward the Sonora  road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay drops the hardtack back from where the bean trails c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Lednov! (tracing) We come along here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing) And meet him there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unless the sheriff gets too close  and he holes up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds out his hand and Hayes hands him his change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve tucks his gun under his arm. As he passes the count he picks up the hardtack and starts eating it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT - ANGLED TOWARD Sheriff's office. Up the street men are gathering around the sheriff's office. Some are  mounted. Some are tightening their cinches. Clay and Stev come out of the store to look up the street. Steve munche the hardtack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (motioning) Sure a lot of guys lookin' for Lednov.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah -- and Lednov's only lookin'  for one man. Me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't like me. What you eatin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lednov.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances at the remaining piece of hardtack and then pi it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay laughs. As they start up the street, the sheriff mou his horse and, followed by his men, rides forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT. A woman's hat lies on the rocky earth. It is big, elaborate affair. O.s. there is the SOUND of hoofbea the SQUEAL of a wagon brake and the JANGLE of harness. CA PULLS BACK and ANGLE WIDENS to reveal Clay's wagon coming down a very steep hill. Steve is driving, holding tightly the reins and riding the brake. Seeing the hat, he yells Clay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another one, Clay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay rides over and, swinging down, picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLED DOWN hill. The road twists tortuously down. Near t bottom it swings sharply at right angles into a dry wash. The banks shut out further view of the road. Near where t road turns a trunk lies at the side. It has broken open a some of the contents are spilled out in the dust. Clay ri to it, reins in his horse and looks down. Steve, with  difficulty, pulls the mules to a stop alongside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: featuring trunk and wagon. Clay swings out of his saddle, starts tossing the clothes back in the trunk. Steve jumps down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sure must have been travelin'.  This keeps up we can start a store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things get tough next winter, you'll  have somethin' to wear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve holds up a petticoat close to his body and grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd look good doin' the ploughin' in  this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay takes it from him, puts it in the trunk and shuts th lid. Steve helps him hoist the trunk into the wagon bed.  Steve gets back in the seat. Just as Clay is about to mou he stops and picks up a small folding daguerrotype case  delicately ornamented. He lifts his eyebrow, tucks the ca into his pocket, then mounts and starts ahead around the  bend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay's ANGLE. Ahead, off the road in the wash is the surr that passed Graham's buckboard at the fork. Clay spurs hi horse forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on surrey. The back wheel is broken and the bed of the su rests on the ground. The horses have been taken from the  traces and stand dejectedly in the hot sun. A blanket is  spread in the scant shade thrown by the surrey. On it lie Elaine and, sitting beside her, is Marcia. A damp cloth i spread across Elaine's forehead. A water bag hangs from t surrey. Elaine's head is pillowed on a dainty satin cushi Helen and Mary have risen at Clay's approach and now stan by the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay gallops forward to pull up near the surrey. In the b Steve drives the wagon around the bend. Clay dismounts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay drops his reins and hurries up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anybody hurt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. We came down the hill a little  fast and... (rueful) ...the wheel broke. (hopefully) Can you fix it for us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay bends over Elaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter with her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dryly) Too much excitement. How about the  surrey. Can you fix it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay turns from Elaine and gives his attention to the sur

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on rear of surrey. In the B.g. Steve pulls the wagon to a stop, jumps off, and comes running over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimininy. You sure were lucky, just  bustin' a wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen moves toward Clay. She miles without humor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rubbing thigh) You think that'sall we busted -- You  should see...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay stops her with a look, goes around, and kicks the  unbroken back wheel. The spokes rattle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This must have been in the family a  long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dryly) It was a gift from the citizens of  Aspen. I'm Mary Wells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him to see if the name registers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this is Helen Carter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Clay Phillips. (motioning) My brother Steve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve tugs at his battered hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shy) Pleased to meet you, ma'am. (brightly) We found your trunk. Were you doin'  the driven'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was at first. Then I was hanging  on. (to Clay) Are you going far?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As far as -- Sonora?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary and Helen exchange glances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to Sonora, too, so that  solves everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay takes the makings from his pocket, starts to roll a  cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can ride in your wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve looks at Clay hopefully. He likes the prospect of h these lovely women along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We wouldn't think of asking you to  take us for nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay finishes the cigarette, starts to put the makings ba Mary holds out her hand. Clay gives her the makings. Mary speaks as she casually rolls a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's only four of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay motions to the remuda that grazes in the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got eleven horses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (proudly) Morgan blood. The beat in Nevada.  Clay and me have a place on the  Toulomne River. We're going to raise  horses like these.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary has finished rolling her cigarette. She passes the b to Helen, who starts rolling one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They won't be riding in the wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dryly) Did you ever try taking a bunch of  horses over Sonora Pass? It's quite  a job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't leave us here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Course I can't. I'll give you a lift  to the first ranch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen has finished her cigarette. She passes the makings Steve. He hesitates, looks at his brother and, when he se Clay is occupied with Mary, starts rolling one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What good is it going to do us to go  to some ranch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amiably) You can stay here if you like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to get to Sonora. There are  jobs waiting for us there. We'll pay  you for your trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not running a stage line, ma'am,  and I can't take a chance on losing  the horses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve finishes his cigarette. Again he hesitates, then no wanting to seem young in front of these women he takes a  bold step and lights it. Clay reaches over and takes it f him. Mary watches the byplay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you're old enough to smoke,  I'll tell you. (kind) Get the horses started on ahead,  will you, Steve?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve, embarrassed and hurt, turns quickly away. Helen lo after the boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Afraid it will stop him growin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning) Let's get your stuff in the wagon.  Like I said, I'll take you to the  first ranch. I wish I could carry  you all the way, but I can't. It's a  tough trip and women would be in the  way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dryly) Our kind of women?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignores that) You'll have to drive -- except down  hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lifts some things out of the surrey and carries them t the wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you're going about this all  wrong. Why not try telling him we'll  do the cookin' and mendin' and washin'  for him. That usually works. (then shocked at the  thought) Yeah, but suppose he took us up on  it. Where would we be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe in Sonora.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts around the surrey. Helen follows. Clay bends over Elaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter with her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dryly) Too much excitement. Or maybe it's  just the heat. How about the surrey.  Can you fix it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Clay turns from Elaine, Marcia joins the other two, th attention on Clay and the surrey. Left alone, Elaine is  suddenly alert and no longer sick. She glances around, th unobserved slides out from under the shade of the surrey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on rear of surrey. In the B.g. Steve pulls the wagon to a stop, jumps off, and comes running over. Elaine stands fo moment, searching the ground with her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jiminy. You sure were lucky, just  bustin' a wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen moves toward Clay. She smiles without humor. With t new diversion, Elaine, still unnoticed, starts away -- ba toward where they dropped the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rubbing thigh) You think that's all we busted --  You should see...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sees Elaine) Now where's she goin'? --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (half-turns without  stopping) I -- lost something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wouldn't happen to be this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine stops now and turns as Clay takes the folding  daguerrotype case from his pocket. Elaine, her eyes wide frightened, starts back as Mary takes the case from Clay opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's the old folks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frantic) Give it to me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She jerks the case from Mary's hands, snaps it shut, and  stands staring at Mary with a strange mixture of fright,  anger and hysteria. Mary glances around as if to say what did-I-do? To cover the embarrassed silence, Clay kicks th unbroken back wheel. The spokes rattle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This must have been in the family a  long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine glances at him as though he had insulted her, turn and starts toward the blanket again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dryly) It was a gift from the citizens of  Aspen. I'm Mary Wells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him to see if the name registers. At the sur side, Elaine is abruptly weak again. She leans against it for support. Mareia moves to her as she slides back down the blanket, clutching the case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this is Helen Carter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Clay Phillips. (motioning) My brother Steve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve tugs at his battered hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shy) Pleased to meet you, ma'am. (brightly) We found your trunk. Were you doin'  the drivin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary and Helen come around the end of the surrey to where Elaine lies. Mary bends beside the sick girl and lifts th cloth from the girl's forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Honeybunch. We're changing  trains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sick girl sits up. She looks around her dully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nice, kind wrangler is letting us  ride in his wagon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Assisted by Mary, Elaine gets to her feet. Mary puts her around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...as far as the first ranch. From  then on --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine stops. She looks fearfully up at Helen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What ranch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the difference?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She tries to lead the girl toward the wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fierce) Ask him what ranch --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's plenty of time for that. (sharp) Come on, now. You've got to lie down  out of this sun. Stop worrying. I'll  find out what ranch after a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pulls the girl with her toward the wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on wagon. Clay, in the wagon bed, is stowing his gear in back. Mary, supporting Elaine, reaches the wagon. Seeing girls, Clay reaches down and gently lifts Elaine up. Mary climbs in beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: wagon bed. Clay has unrolled a bedroll under the seat whe there is a little shade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (kind) Stretch out under the seat, Miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (desperate) Which ranch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's worried about where you're  taking us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she speaks, Mary helps the girl down under the seat, t rises to face Clay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dryly) So am I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a nice place owned by an old  couple named Wyatt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine as she hears the name. She is shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll take you in until you can  make other arrangements.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay and Mary. Clay vaults out of the wagon, CAMERA ANGLE WIDENS, he looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So both of you stop worrying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns away and hurries back to the surrey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT. Dust rises over the road as the cavalcade move forward. Clay, rifle across his lap, rides in front. The  wagon, with Mary driving and Helen beside her on the seat follows. The two horses that pulled the surrey are tied t the tail gate. Then comes the remuda with Steve bringing the rear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcia and Elaine. PROCESS. Marcia sits in the bed of the wagon looking back. Elaine lies under the seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve. Steve proudly carries his new rifle across his lap He whistles happily as he scans the desert country hopefu for the enemy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT. Long shadows of the hills lie on the grassy me along the stream that is bordered by cottonwoods and will A knoll overlooks the camp site. The caravan can be seen it halts in the lush grass a few yards from the stream. T girls sit lifelessly on the wagon; they seem too tired to dismount. Then, finally, Marcia helps Elaine to climb sti down. With the exception of Mary they all let themselves  down in the grass. Mary walks to the head of the team and starts fumbling with the harness. Steve comes into the sc dismounts quickly and pulls the saddle off his horse. The remuda has fanned out, the horses moving toward the water Steve crosses to Mary and takes over the job of unbucklin the harness. Mary smiles gratefully and rubs her hand acr her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve, see the horses don't drink  too much --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve straightens, looks towards the horses and moves off He speaks to Mary over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave that unharnessing for me, Ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary smiles after him, then moves across the grass, CAMER DOLLYING AHEAD of her. She sinks to her knees in the patc of sand by the stream and leans down and puts her face un the water. Then, sitting up, she wipes the water and dust from her face with a handkerchief. Clay rides up from beh dismounts, scoops up some water from the river in the bri of his hat and drinks it. For a second he watches Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a place down a ways, where  you and the girls can wash some of  that dust off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary's manner is business-like. She and the girls are alo for the ride. She wants no favors -- wants to do her part

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. And isn't there something we  can do about supper -- or making the  beds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (half-smile) Steve and me, we use a saddle for a  pillow and roll up in a tarp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (curt) But you eat, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mostly, we open a can of beans and  boil some coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you keep the can opener?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the grub box. (softening) Toward morning the dew gets kind of  heavy so maybe you better fix up a  bed under the wagon. Spread some  bunch grass under the tarp and the  ground won't be so hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and leads his horse back to the wagon, stands th unsaddling it. Mary rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcia -- all of you. Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts downstream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLED PAST wagon. Clay tosses the saddle into the wagon  bed, slaps his mare on the rump. She trots off. Climbing on the wheel, he gets the grub box under the seat and lif it down. Steve comes from out of scene and starts unharne the team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to be casual) Where'd they go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swimming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay comes past him, carrying the grub box. He puts it do near where some stones make a crude firebox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's sort of nice having company  along. Not so lonesome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay squats by the stones and starts building a fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you get the team watered, rustle  up some wood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He fans the small flame with his hat. Steve leads the mul down toward the stream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLED PAST Clay. In the B.g. Steve stands by the stream, letting the team drink. O.s. the women can be heard laugh and splashing. Steve gives all his attention to what is g on downstream. Clay puts wood on the fire, opens the grub box. He sees Steve, takes the coffee pot out of the box a heads for the stream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLED PAST Steve downstream. Behind the willows the girl are bathing. However they are too far away to be seen cle and the willows make a fairly effective screen. Clay walk upstream and fills the coffee pot, then comes back to sta for a moment beside Steve. Steve, who hadn't seen Clay un now, suddenly gets very busy giving all his attention to mules.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to mules) You boys have had enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He jerks them from the water and leads them away. Clay fr after him, then goes back to the wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on wagon and fire. As Clay passes the wagon, he reaches i the bed and gets a couple of strips of scrap iron. These carries to the fire. He puts the iron strips across the b sets the coffee pot on, feeds the fire with some more woo then going back to the wagon, he takes his rifle out, thr a shell into the chamber and starts off up the knoll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT. It is a moonlight night. Clay squats on his he smoking. The rifle lies across his knees. Below can be se the campfire, and the shadowy forms of the girls as with  Steve's help they make up a bed under the wagon and cook evening meal. Clay suddenly reacts as O.s. a horse whinni Standing he looks off into the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLED PAST Clay. In the moonlight the trail stretches ba over rolling hills. Faintly can be heard the SOUND of  hoofbeats. Below, where the remuda grazes, a horse whinni again. Clay moves down toward the camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the camp. As Clay approaches. Steve squats by the fire. H has spread out a tarp in the circle of firelight and Mary setting the tin plates, cups, etc., out. Elaine, a blanke around her, sits near the fire. She looks tired and ill.  Marcia and Helen are struggling with bed-making under the wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm the girl who used to complain  to my mother about helping with the  wash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve and Mary look up as Clay strides up. Clay starts ki dirt over the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get your rifle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve jumps up and hurries to the wagon. Clay continues  kicking dirt over the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT - ANGLES PAST horseman. The horseman, who has b approaching from the east, tops a rise and looks off at t camp. He is a shadowy figure in the palo dark. For a mome as the fire still blazes, figures are visible in the camp Then the fire goes out. The horseman dismounts, pulling h rifle from his scabbard. Moving to his horse's head he pu a hand on the animal's nostrils. He looks toward the camp for a moment then starts cautiously along the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT - ANGLED THROUGH willows PAST Clay and Steve. T brothers have taken up a post overlooking the road. The  horseman walks cautiously toward them. He stops, listenin Then he drops his reins and comes forward stealthily. The horse stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay and Steve. Steve, finger on trigger gives Clay a  questioning glance. Clay shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) Hold it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on road. The man, now seen clearly for the first time, st He is Jim Clayton, a man in his twenties, chunky, round-f stolid and not too imaginative. He wears the well-worn je and blue shirt of the farmer. Clay and Steve come out of willows toward him. Both have their rifles ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drop your gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clayton hesitates, then lets his rifle butt drop to the r

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mildly) Drop yours. I'm gunshy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then don't come sneakin' around a  man's camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fellow sees a fire go out all of a  sudden, he don't take chances. My  name's Clayton and I'm looking for  someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay and Steve lower their rifles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found their surrey --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So did I. They were in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a friend -- took off this  morning sort of sudden while I wasn't  around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay moves closer and extends his hand. They shake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very cordial) I'm glad you came along. (introducing) My brother, Steve. I'm Phillips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve shakes Jim's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gave the girls a lift. Didn't know  what else to do with them. Get your  horse and come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clayton turns back toward his horse. Clay and Steve wait him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT - ANGLED BACK ALONG the trail. Mary and Helen,  tense and worried, stand at the edge of the camp, looking off. Marcia is with Elaine under the wagon. From o.s. com the SOUND of men's voices. Clay, Steve and Clayton, leadi his horse, come into view.

dialogues.speaker: WAGON
dialogues.text: Marcia kneeling on the tarp by Elaine, is staring ahead.  Suddenly her face lights up. She springs to her feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay, Steve and Jim are now close to Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (genial) Here's a man says he's looking for  you girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Miss Wells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hearing his voice, Marcia runs toward them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcia throws herself into Jim's arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clayton kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was roundin' up some stock. That's  why I didn't come sooner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcia hugs him. In the B.g. Clay goes over to the fire,  kicks the dirt off the embers and piles on wood. The fire flares up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean running off without  a word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary and Helen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know who to tell, it all  happened so sudden, those people  comin' and throwin' us out on the  street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you think about it, darlin'.  Don't you think about anythin' but  us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Looks like we lose a good piano  player.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA ANGLE WIDENS as Marcia and Jim come forward. The f now burns briskly. Clay rejoins the group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (happily) Jim came after me, Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dryly) I see he did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a milk pail in one hand and a  marriage license in the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharp) Why didn't you say you wanted to get  married back in Aspen. I told the  man in Sonora there were four of us.  If only three show up, he might call  the whole deal off. We've got to  stick together. Like we've always  done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got a chance to get married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly) That's what I'm gettin' at. It never  works. Don't forget we were thrown  out of Aspen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim doesn't care, do you, Jim?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary speaks before Jim can answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Jim isn't the only one you're  marrying. He has folks and friends.  What are they going to say? And how're  they going to feel? I tell you, it  won't work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The joy goes out of Marcia's expression. She looks up at  Jim, her eyes begging him to tell her it will work. Jim, naturally shy man, loses his tongue momentarily. Clay jum into the breach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course it'll work. You can get  another girl to fill out the act.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring him) And look at it this way. How about  Jim -- it puts him in a sort of tough  spot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what I'm doing. My folks got  nothin' to do with it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've talked this over with them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They know about Marcia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly) And they don't like the idea!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suppose they don't. This is his  problem. He's over twenty-one. He  wants to marry Marcia and Marcia  wants to marry him so let 'em alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary turns on Clay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay and Mary. The others in the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you were in his shoes would you  take one of us home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not in his shoes, so leave me  out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA ANGLE WIDENS as he turns back to the fire, embarra by the spot he's in, and throws wood on it, Mary watching him. Steve comes over to Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (friendly) I would!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay swings around and comes back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hurriedly; smiles) Steve maybe you better get some wood  for the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you, Mr. Phillips?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Steve) Go on, there's a good boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay gives Steve a gentle push. Steve exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitter) Don't you want him to hear your  answer? Well, I know what it is. For  the other fellow it's all right --  but not you. All you want is to get  rid of one of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim, his arm around Marcia, moves closer. Helen is in the B.g., watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No need of you two arguin' about  this. We know what we want to do,  and nothin' either of you says makes  any difference. We want to go home --  tonight. (to Clay) Will you sell me one of your horses?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I can't do that. I went a  long way to get those horses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, we'll ride double. Come  on, Marcia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taking her arm he leads her to where the horse stands at edge of the camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: featuring Marcia and Jim. In the B.g. Mary comes after th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No need to do that, Marcia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim and Marcia turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got two horses and they're  four of us. So half of one of 'em is  yours. (smiling) The other half's a wedding present.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcia comes over to hug Mary. As Marcia and Jim leave, M moves to Clay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big-hearted fella. Can't see young  love thwarted -- especially if it  makes one less girl to worry about.  That's all you really want, isn't  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT. Mary stands in the moonlight by the wagon, loo out across the meadow. Below, near the creek, the horses  graze. There is the soft jangle of a bell as the bell mar moves her head. Clay comes walking up from the creek, rif in hand. He passes without noticing Mary. Mary turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary in close F.g. The campfire burns low. Steve lies on stomach close to it. Clay stops beside him to glance down then moves on to sit on a rock above the fire. Mary start toward the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve. Open in front of him is a copy of Leslie's Weekly, woman's journal: pictures of baby basinettes, whale-bone  corsets, fancy oil lamps, etc. Mary comes into scene to s above him, looking down. Steve glances up and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that your kind of reading, Steve?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't read, Ma'am. I just look at  the pictures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLED DOWN PAST Clay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't read?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She glances up where Clay sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your brother's always looked after  you, hasn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since I can remember, Ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he just never troubled to have  you get any schooling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay. He listens, perturbed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary and Steve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't Clay's fault. We've been  moving around most all the time --  mebbe when we get the ranch and stay  in one place I can learn my letters  then --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you even know your letters?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay. He winces at!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, Steve and Clay. Behind them, Clay rises and comes d nearer the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to learn them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sure would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I could start you out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That'd be swell. (shyly) You know, you're an awful lot  different than I thought you'd be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gives him a quick look of inquiry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're so nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did someone say I wasn't nice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no. Nobody said nothing to me.  Only I got the idea that -- well  Clay and me used to be walking through  town and there was your place and  through the window I could see you  dancing, but Clay always took me  over to the other side of the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Time to go to bed, Steve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve looks up, then rises reluctantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Miss Wells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Steve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve exits. Mary looks after him, then up at Clay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (soft) There's a nice boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharp) That why you always took him on the  other side of the street?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay kicks loose embers into the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharper) Maybe I don't make the grade in some  ways, but I know enough to teach a  kid his letters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay turns from the fire to stand above her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quiet) He doesn't know his letters, no --  but he knows the names of animals...  he knows what roots to eat when you're  clear out of food... He knows the  difference between a possum and a  coon just by lookin' at the tracks...  more than most trappers know... and  he can tell whether she'll rain or  shine tomorrow by smelling the air  tonight. There's a lot of things he  doesn't know, I hope he'll never  learn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pauses, looking down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning away) Like sticking his nose into other  people's business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay moves out of the circle of firelight to stop and pic up his rifle, tarp and blanket, then climbs the knoll. Ma stares into the fire, then rising she starts toward the w

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT. Clay reaches the top of the knoll and stands  looking off. Below him the campfire burns low. Mary reach the wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT ANGLED PAST Mary TOWARD Clay. Mary stops, looki up. A match flares as Clay lights a cigarette. O.s. there the SOUND of the bell mare's bell, the SOUND of horses mo restlessly. Mary turns, looks under the wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine is gone. Helen is asleep. Mary drops to her knees the tarp and shakes Helen in wakefulness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Elaine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen sits up and looks over at Elaine's side of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was here a while ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary straightens, moves down past the wagon, CAMERA PANNI WITH her. She calls softly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Elaine!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay. He looks down toward the wagon as Mary calls Elaine name again, this time louder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine. (then) Clay -- Elaine's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay frowns, pitches his cigarette away and starts down t the wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve. He is sitting up, pulling on his boots. From under the bedclothes he takes his rifle and starts toward the w

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: wagon. Clay stands with Mary at the wagon as Steve comes Helen is sitting up in bed, a comforter pulled around her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She can't have gone far. I wasn't  asleep long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would she run off for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excited) Because she's sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts away into the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharp) Stay here. One woman wanderin' off's  enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary turns back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you worry, Miss Wells. We'll  find her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay picks up his saddle and bridle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mary) Build the fire up and stick close to  it. Come on, Steve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts down toward the meadow. Steve follows. Helen  scrambles out from under the wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay stops by the creek. Behind him the fire smoulders ne the wagon. Mary's shadowy figure can be seen climbing the knoll where Clay's bedroll is. Helen is near the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (annoyed) Look around. She can't have gone  far.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve nods and splashes across the creek to follow the ro leading west. Clay starts toward the meadow where the hor graze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT. Steve moves slowly along the road away from ca He is scanning the dust for Elaine's footprints.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT - ANGLED PAST Mary. Mary stands on the knoll lo off. Far below, in the meadow, Clay saddles his horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) Elaine -- Elaine -- Elaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT. Clay swings into the saddle, and rides east. O Mary calls:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine -- Elaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the call echoes across the hills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT. This is rough country, the rocky hills covered sparsely with scrub pinon pine and brush. Steve stands on rise. He looks around for a moment, then turning starts b down the slope. Suddenly he stops and listens, as from O. comes the SOUND of distant sobbing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve. He listens, trying to locate the sound then he hur down into a dry wash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve crashes through the brush into the wash, to stop be Elaine who sits with her head buried in her arms, sobbing

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve and Elaine. Steve drops on his knees beside her. El doesn't look up. Steve shakes her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma'am -- you shouldn't have run off  like that. Why I was just about to  give up lookin'. Come on, now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't stay here. There's snakes  and it's cold and you'll just get  sicker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suppose that Lednov was to have found  you, instead of me. Why you wouldn't  have had a chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharp) I said I didn't care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's botherin' you, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls her up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Runnin' off and worryin' people.  Makin' it tougher on Clay than it is  already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hysterical) Don't ask me because I won't tell  you! I won't tell anybody! Go away!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't act so -- crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dully) I'm sorry. Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (relieved) That's a good girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA ANGLE WIDENS as he tucks her arm in the crook of h own and starts up the other side of the wash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve, holding Elaine's arm, scrambles up the bank and th the brush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it. Watch out where you're  steppin' --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops and looks off. Faintly O.s. is heard the SOUND o hoofbeats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That oughta be -- (then sharp) Down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shoves the girl down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: their ANGLE. Over a hill comes a horseman to be followed another and then a third.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve and Elaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lednov --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excitedly he swings the rifle to his shoulder and fires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT - Clay reins his horse in and turns to look off the direction from which the shot came. Faintly o.s. anot shot echoes across the hills, then another and another. C spurs his horse and gallops off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay gallops up the hill to rein his horse in suddenly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: his ANGLE. Riding toward him are several horsemen. The ho move at a walk. One carries a double burden. Steve walks  along behind. Clay spurs his horse and rides down toward  them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay, in the B.g., comes down the hill. The horsemen, sev of them, with Sheriff Gardner in the lead, followed by a  deputy, carrying Elaine in front of him, file past camera Steve, hands in his pockets, walks dejectedly in the dust cloud kicked up by the horses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: featuring Clay and Gardner. Clay reins in his horse besid Gardner, who also stops. The others rein in. Steve stops short distance away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want to take her off our hands?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay rides closer. The deputy rides forward and lifts Ela into his arms. Clay settles her in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who shot who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody. The light was bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are two rifles in his saddle holster. He pulls Stev out, hands it over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve's!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay shoves it in his saddle holster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's she doin' runnin' around the  country at night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't know. Did you ask her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I can get out of her is she don't  care about livin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look of things, she doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Keep a closer eye on her -- (motioning to Steve) And him. Shootin' going on, we'll  never find Lednov.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wheels his horse and rides off, followed by the others Clay watches him go. Reluctantly Steve moves slowly up to stand near Clay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was only three of them at first.  I guess I lost my head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dryly) How'd you happen to miss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were quite a ways off and the  wind was blowin'. I didn't have them  to aim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good thing you didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reins his horse around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay looks back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man can't help gettin' excited  once in a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, Steve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I have my gun back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. You'll find it under the wagon  seat. Like I said before, a twenty- two's more your size.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXTREME LONG SHOT. West are the Sierras and clouds are pi in untidy heaps on the range. The dusty trail runs throug rolling country. Pinon pine and brush clothe the slopes. wagon and horses are the moving center of a white cloud o dust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay's party. Clay rides in the lead. The wagon follows a Steve is riding beside the wagon. Behind is the remuda, a the horses are straying off the road in search of grass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: wagon - (MOVING). Featuring Steve and Mary. Elaine lies u the seat and Helen sits beside her. Steve is reciting the alphabet to a simple melody usually sung by children of s or seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stumbles embarrassedly) Gee, I can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? You went farther than that  last time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm too old for it, Miss Wells...  That's for little kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be silly... Nobody's too old  to learn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (resolutely) Okay. A-B-C -- D-E-F -- G-H-I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay. He turns in his saddle where he rides ahead of the  team. He notices Steve riding at Mary's side and reins in his horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mildly) Oh, Steve!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve and Mary. Steve stops his letters. looks off. The w moves up to Clay and stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get back to the horses. They're  straggling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's learning his letters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. While the horses wander all  over the country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve hesitates hoping he'll change his mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sternly) Do like I said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve wheels his horse and rides back. Mary looks over at Clay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dryly) Learnin' to read has nothing to do  with the right or the wrong side of  the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (motioning) Are the horses stragglin' or aren't  they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a backward  glance) They're stragglin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His letters will keep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wheels his horse and rides after Steve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve is driving the horses back into the road. Clay ride up to help him. The horses fall in behind the wagon. Stev takes up his position in the rear. Clay rides over beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve -- I want you to learn to read.  I meant to teach you but I never  seemed to find time. I figured when  we got settled on the ranch we'd get  around to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ride in silence for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right with me if she teaches  you, but I don't want you forgettin'  your job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flat) I won't again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the horses strays out of line and Clay rides out a gets the animal back in the road. Then he returns to Stev

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't like other trips we've  taken. For one thing, we've got a  wagonload of women. For another  there's a guy wanderin' around hopin'  to put a bullet in my back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve looks over at his brother and finds a wry grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okeh, I was wrong. But you can't  expect a fellow who never saw Lednov  and never heard his name until a  while ago to do too much worryin'.  You've been sorta close mouthed about  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I have. You were pretty little  when they locked him up. I don't  suppose you even remember that time  I was gone two months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure I remember. You went to Mexico  lookin' for cattle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods; then, after a  moment) You remember Jeff Rawson? -- We used  to go fishing and hunting with him  when you were so high.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (offended) Sure I do. Went off down to Mexico  or something...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I told you then. Only he  didn't. Lednov killed him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... that's the time you went away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) I caught up with Lednov in Nogales.  He didn't like the idea of comin'  back across the border but he came.  I turned him over to the sheriff and --  that's the story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking off) Maybe you shoulda killed him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I should. But I was never much  on killin'. Anyway, he moved too  quick and I just got him through the  shoulder. (glances off) Looks pretty peaceful up ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you never can tell. Why don't  you get that new rifle out of the  wagon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve smiles warmly at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And while you're there you might as  well find out what comes after K.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cavalcade. It moves through dry barren hills. Far off, th Sierras rise against the sky Thunder heads are piled in u heaps on the range.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: sky. Dark rain clouds blown by a high wind. SOUND of thun

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: rain -- the caravan. Clay leads it through a rain that ha filled the ruts in the trail, soaked the horses to gliste black -- and obscures all view of the country through whi they are passing. SOUND of rain falling is loud. Clay and Steve both wear slickers, gleaming from their shoulders t the rumps of their horses. Mary, a tarp around her should drives. Elaine and Helen huddle under a tarpaulin in the  wagon bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: rain -- DOWN ANGLE -- wagon moving. Elaine sits up and, i her delirium, throws off the tarp. Helen tries to pull he down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crying out) Elaine -- stop it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: rain -- Clay. He wheels his horse at the SOUND of Helen's voice and rides back through the rain toward the wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: rain -- wagon. Mary pulls on the reins and the mules stop Twisting them around the whip-stock, she swings back into the wagon bed. She looks up at Clay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She should be in bed where it's dry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In her anxiety, her tone is accusing. Clay drops the rein climbs into the wagon and bends down beside Elaine. He pu his hand on her forehead.
