dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: rain - DOWN ANGLE - featuring Clay and Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dryly) Yes, Ma'am, she should...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts fixing the tarp so it gives more protection to sick girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the nearest shelter's the Wyatt  ranch and that's maybe five hours  away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we get a doctor at that ranch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (straightening) No, Ma'am, we can't. We can get a  roof and a fire and maybe Mrs. Wyatt  knows something about taking care of  sick people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: rain. Clay vaults out of the wagon and mounts his horse.  Mary rises and climbs back into the seat. She lashes the  mules with the reins. The wagon jolts forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: rain - ANGLED ACROSS seat - (MOVING). Clay rides alongsid Then, without a word, he strips off his slicker, tosses i on the seat and rides off. Mary looks after him, then at slicker. She hesitates, not wanting to take favors from h Then she pulls the slicker around her. Taking the whip, s hits the mules. CAMERA ANGLE WIDENS and CAMERA HOLDS. The team breaks into a trot. The cavalcade moves away from ca through drenching rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT - ANGLED THROUGH gate in barbed wire fence. The ranch is nestled in a valley at the base of the Sierras.  Green meadowland surrounds the farm buildings which consi of a cabin, barn and sheds, all in good repair and white- washed, as are the corral fences and the picket fence aro the house, which stands in a clump of trees. The wind has pushed the clouds back over the hills, but far off there still thunder. The gate in front f.g. is of barbed wire. is closed. On the fence post a board is tacked. Neatly  lettered on the board is the name:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From o.s. comes the SOUND of horses moving restlessly and the creaking of saddle leather, as a man swings out of th saddle. Footsteps approach. A man's head and shoulders, b to camera, comes into scene. He unloops the strand of bai wire and lets the gate fall open, then turns and we see h face. He is Lednov. His cheek and jowls have a dark growt of beard. He wears a black leather jacket and a wrangler' grey hat. The clothes Forster was wearing. As he moves ba to his horse, CAMERA PULLS BACK and PANS AROUND. His companions, McCall and Peters, also wear black leathe jackets, sombre, dusty pants and hats. They are mounted o matched roans. The horses are winded, lathered and dirty. is obvious they have ridden hard. Lednov strides forward as he reaches for the reins the horse shies away. Brutall he jerks on the reins. The horse rears. He snatches his h from his head and whacks the horse across the nose. McCal rides over and grabs the reins. Lednov scrambles into the saddle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLED TOWARD gate. Lednov rides forward through the gate His horse is limping badly. The others follow. They do no stop to put the gate back up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT. Clay's cavalcade moves forward along the trail There are cloud patches overhead and faintly in the back  country thunder rumbles. The mules pull the jolting wagon forward in a slow trot. Clay rides ahead. Steve and the r follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT. Lednov, McCall and Peters ride into the yard a up to the horses' trough. The horses plunge their muzzles deep into the trough. As the men dismount, Wyatt, a sinew little man, hurries from the direction of the barn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: at horse trough. Wyatt, smiling his pleasure, comes up as the three men dismount.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (happily) My name's Wyatt. Certainly glad you  boys dropped in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He extends his hand to Lednov. Lednov ignores it. The thr men are looking around them. Two work horses, fat and eld amble across the corral to nuzzle the roans through the f

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those the only horses you got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wyatt is a little taken aback by Lednov's manner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, yes. They're all I need...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mine's gone lame. Take a look at  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wyatt frowns up at Lednov, angered by the order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, we haven't got all day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCall and Peters move closer to Wyatt, who glances aroun worriedly. Realizing he better do as he's told, he goes t the roan and rubs his ears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa, boy. Let's have a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bending, he lifts the horse's hoof. Lednov, McCall and Pe watch him. He drops the hoof, straightens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He dropped a shoe. You shouldn't be  ridin' him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put on another one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That won't help the stone bruise.  You ain't been around horses much,  looks like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you quit gabbin' and do what  you're told.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wyatt hesitates. Lednov steps toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frightened, bewildered) All right, but it won't do much good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up the roan's reins and starts leading him into corral. Lednov, with a jerk of his thumb, indicates that  McCall is to go with him. McCall follows. Lednov and Pete turn toward the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Lednov and Peters start for the house, Mrs. Wyatt, a w of about fifty, small, plump, browned from the sun and ha from work, comes out on the porch. She has taken off her  apron and holds it in her hand. She smiles at the two men

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLED PAST Mrs. Wyatt. She starts down the steps as Ledn and Peters come up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was up to my elbows in flour when  you boys rode up, that's why I din't  come out sooner. I hope Ed asked you  to stay the night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All we want's supper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At his tone, the welcoming smile leaves her face. She loo from one to the other. Lednov pushes past her up the step and into the house. Mrs. Wyatt follows him with her glanc McCall motions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're in a hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT. In the f.g. the cavalcade moves along the trai Now the Sierras back of the Wyatt ranch are much closer. sun has set but it is still light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT. Peters sprawls on the ground, smoking. He look up as Wyatt and McCall cross from the direction of the ba

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take care of that horse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gruffly) Yeah. The best I could.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wyatt goes on past and hurries up the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLED PAST Wyatt. This is the main room of the house -- living room and kitchen combined: wood-stove against one  wall, a sink with a pump against another, a fireplace, so simple furniture and, hanging from one of the rough walls concertina. Through an open doorway can be seen the Wyatt bedroom. Another door, closed, leads into the second bedr The house has a warm, well-scrubbed look. Wyatt enters. Mrs. Wyatt, stoking the stove, turns. She glances nervous in the direction of the bedroom. Wyatt shifts his glance the fireplace -- there is no gun hanging from the hooks a the mantel. Lednov appears in the doorway of the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doin' --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lookin' around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He crosses to the fireplace. He is carrying Wyatt's rifle gun belt and six gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These all the shells you got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wyatt has had as much of this as he can stand. He starts  angrily across the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put my guns down and get out of here --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed -- no, Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She crosses to him and stands in his way. Wyatt pushes pa her and grabs for the guns. Lednov gives him a swipe with the back of his hand, knocking him away easily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your old woman's got sense -- you  listen to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Wyatt helps Ed to his feet. She puts an arm around h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I asked you -- these all the shells  you got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly) They's a box in the cupboard over  the sink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lednov crosses to the cupboard and opens it. Finding the of shells, he slips it in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ed) Get on about your chores. (to Mrs. Wyatt) And hurry that grub up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wyatt and his wife look at each other. Then meekly they o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT. Here the trail starts down into the valley. Fr o.s. comes the SOUND of the cavalcade approaching. Clay r into the scene and stops on the hilltop to glance ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay's ANGLE. A light can be seen ahead in the valley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay turns and rides back toward the wagon. The mules hav slowed to a walk in the climb up the hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on wagon - (MOVING). Clay rides up alongside. Mary is hun forward on the seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only a little ways now -- maybe a  mile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances down into the wagon bed where Helen is sitting Elaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's she makin' out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dryly) If she feels worse than I do, she's  dyin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay rides back toward the rear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) Steve --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yo --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wagon reaches the crest of the hill. Mary hits the mu with the reins. The mules break into a trot. Behind, the  remuda comes into view. Clay sits his horse by the side o the trail and watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT. Mrs. Wyatt stands by the stove, watching the t men at the table. Wyatt sits in a chair by the stove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have some more of that coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lednov pushes his chair back and rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got to get movin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because there's a man I want to see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can wait. Let's stay here until  morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wyatt and his wife exchange frightened glances. That's th last thing they want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising) I said let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (protesting) One night more won't matter. Your  friend'll be there. Anyway I don't  think so much of the idea of prowling  around his ranch. He knows you're  out so he ain't going to sit still  for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fierce) I said I had a guy to see and I'm  going to see him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the fingers of his right hand he automatically rubs shoulder just above the heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gave me something once so I  wouldn't forget.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising) He says go, we go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grudgingly, McCall gives in. They exit. Wyatt stares afte them raging at his impotence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they'd only left me a gun, I'd  fix 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hush, Ed. Hush. They might come back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. FULL SHOT. The three men mount their horse, dig thei spurs in and ride away. As they ride toward the gate, Wya comes out on the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT. Here the trail passes through a narrow draw, t climbs a small rise which overlooks the gate. Clay's cara jogs along the trail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT - DOWN ANGLE. The caravan climbs toward camera. CAMERA PANS AROUND to SHOOT DOWN TOWARD the Wyatt ranch.  Through the gate ride Lednov, McCall and Peters. They sto for a moment then turn right and trot along the fence lin As they disappear, the SOUND of the caravan's approach is heard o.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. FULL SHOT. Clay gallops into the yard and swings out the saddle. The farmhouse is dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLED THROUGH window, PAST Wyatt. Clay opens the gate an hurries up the steps and across the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT. Clay raps on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Wyatt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay Phillips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens. Wyatt comes out. He pumps Clay's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) You can light the lamp. (to Clay) I'm sure glad it's you. We were afraid  those killers might come back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three men on matched roans?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the kitchen a match flares as Mrs. Wyatt lights the la

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, how did you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole state's lookin' for 'em. (dryly) And they're lookin' for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Wyatt comes out to stand in the doorway. She shakes  Clay's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know how good it is to see  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you won't feel that way after  I tell you what I stopped in for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and motions off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANOTHER ANGLE. Clay, Wyatt and Mrs. Wyatt in f.g. The wag is coming toward the yard followed by the remuda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I picked up some women on the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay, Mrs. Wyatt and Wyatt. O.s. the wagon and horses can heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell them to come on in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm going to have to leave 'em  here. They're --- well they're not  the sort of people you're used to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a reprimand) It doesn't matter who they are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lamely) And one of 'em is sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you say so. Go right out  and get her. Ed. build the fire up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns back into the kitchen. Clay looks after her, th hurries down the steps. Wyatt follows his wife inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wyatt goes to the stove and starts stoking the fire. Mrs. Wyatt takes the lamp from the wall bracket and goes into bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT. It is a pleasant room with a large, handmade,  double bed, white flour sack curtains at wide windows. Mr Wyatt puts the lamp on the dresser. Going to the bed she  pulls back the covers, feels the sheets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) Wrap a stove lid in dish towels and  bring it in here. This bed's like  ice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turning from the bed, she crosses to the dresser. Beside dresser is a camel-back trunk. She starts to open a dress drawer, pauses and looks down at the trunk. Moving to the trunk, she hesitates. Then making up her mind, she bends  down and throws open the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOWN ANGLE. A girl's clothing is neatly packed in the tru A framed picture is face down on top of the clothing. Mrs Wyatt kneels by the trunk, pushes the dresses aside and f a nightgown. CAMERA ANGLE WIDENS as she rises and shakes out. It is frilly, dainty, very feminino; obviously the  nightdress of a young girl. She closes the trunk, turns a as she goes to the bed, Wyatt comes through the door carr the towel-wrapped stove lid. She lays the nightgown on th bed, takes the stove lid and puts it between the sheets.  Wyatt is staring down at the garment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cold) Put it back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They face each other. Wyatt reaches out and takes the  nightgown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone might as well get some good  out of it. Wyatt crosses to the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't as if she was dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wyatt opens the trunk, puts the nightgown in and closes t lid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cold) It stays there, understand!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The slamming of a door o.s. interrupts them. They turn an start for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) Right in here, Mr. Phillips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She follows Wyatt to the doorway, CAMERA DOLLYING WITH he She stops in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLED PAST Mrs. Wyatt. Clay, carrying Elaine, bundled in blankets, comes forward. Wyatt has stopped just inside th kitchen. Mary and Helen follow Clay through the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bed's all ready and warm --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stops, staring at the girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Wyatts in the doorway. They recognize the girl. Wyatt expression hardens. Clay, carrying Elaine, pushes between them into the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT. Clay carries the girl to the bed and gently pu her down. Her eyes are closed. Slowly the Wyatts enter th room to stand close together staring at the girl on the b Clay suddenly realizes that something is wrong. He glance up. Elaine opens her eyes and looks up at her mother and  father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly to Wyatt) Go out and make some coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wyatt doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on. You too, Mr Phillips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Clay waits, Wyatt moves through the door unable to arg back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT. Mary and Helen stand close to the steve, looki anxiously toward the bedroom door as Clay and Wyatt come  out. Clay closes the door. Wyatt, dazed by the shock of s his daughter again, stands momentarily staring at the clo door. Then very slowly he turns and looks at Helen and Ma

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: his ANGLE. Mary and Helen, seeing the two men's expressio look from one to the other, puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is she very sick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cold, flat) Get 'em out of here. I won't have  'em in this house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He crosses to the kitchen door, exits, slamming the door  behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) So that was why she tried to run  away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharp) Didn't you know she had a father and  mother out here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hurt and angry) I didn't know anything about her  except she wanted a job because some  man had left her stranded. I couldn't  leave her in the street. Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't stay here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a long walk back to Aspen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turning from them, he exits. Mary and Helen look at each  other. Then Helen grins wryly and goes over to the cupboa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know about you. But I'm not  being thrown out on an empty stomach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT. Wyatt in the f.g. stands by the horse trough. face is set, his expression hard, unyielding. Clay comes  across the yard past the wagon. Wyatt doesn't look at him Clay comes up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay and Wyatt. Clay takes the makings from his pocket, r a cigarette, lights it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry about this, Mr. Wyatt. I  didn't know who she was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quiet) All right, you didn't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't take her with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody asked you to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O.s. Steve whistles the tune of the A B C song as he come out of the barn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just get those two out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve approaches from the barn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not bein' quite fair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's there to be fair about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay and Wyatt. Clay takes the making from his pocket, ro a cigarette, lights it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry about this, Mr. Wyatt. I  didn't know you had a daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quiet) All right, you didn't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't take her with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody asked you to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O.s. Steve whistles the tune of the A B C song as he come out of the barn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just get these two out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve approaches from the barn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not bein' quite fair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's there to be fair about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve comes up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mr. Wyatt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts whistling again as he continues toward the wago

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: wagon. Steve picks up a couple of valises and some blanke and heads for the house, still whistling. In the b.g. can heard the mutter of voices as Clay and Wyatt talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen is sitting at the table, eating a piece of bread an drinking coffee. Mary stands at the window. Steve is hear coming up the steps and across the porch. He pushes the d open and enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cheerfully) Where do I put your things?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary turns from the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back in the wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve stands with his arms full, looking at Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't we stayin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. We're not stayin' --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She crosses to him and smiles wryly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything's all mixed up, so don't  ask questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (soft) Go on, Steve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. CLOSE. Steve stops on the porch. He is puzzled, worr He glances back then over toward the fence where Wyatt an Clay are talking. He shrugs and starts off toward the wag

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT. Mary crosses to the stove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down and eat, why don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary lifts the stove lid and puts a stick in the firebox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't like this was the first  place we were ever thrown out of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not what's worryin' me. Why  didn't she tell us? Maybe we could  have done somethin' -- gone somewhere  else -- puttin' a poor sick kid  through this --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quit worryin' about Elaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She motions to the bedroom door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's home, isn't she? So worry about  us. We want to get to Sonora.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Footsteps across the porch. The two girls look toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: SHOOTING PAST Mary. The door slowly opens. Wyatt enters. crosses to the bedroom door, CAMERA PANNING WITH him. It as though he doesn't see the two women. He stands in fron of the door, staring at it. Then his hand moves to the kn Slowly he turns the knob and opens the door. The two girl watch him as he hesitates on the threshold. Then he enter and closes the door softly. Helen looks over at Mary and  smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT as Wyatt stops, looking at Elaine, resting back against the pillow, seeming very young in the nightgown. a moment it is difficult to know what is in Wyatt's mind. Then he sees the twin tintypes. CAMERA MOVES TOWARD Wyatt face as tears come to his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT as footsteps cross the porch and the screen doo creaks open. Clay enters the kitchen, carrying the girls' suitcases and some blankets. He nods to the girls, then g to the door leading to the other bedroom. There he stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This will be your room until Mr.  Wyatt finds time to take you to the  nearest stage station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he carries their belongings in:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is lighted only by the moonlight. Mary and Helen are in the big four poster bed, close to the window. Clay footsteps are heard on the porch. The kitchen door closes softly. There is the rattle of a stove lid being lifted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) That sounds like him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary slides out of bed and slips into a robe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This time don't talk about cooking!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay turns from the stove to the cupboard over the sink a takes down a coffee cup. The door into Elaine's bedroom i closed. The door into Mary's bedroom opens and Mary enter the kitchen. He turns back to the stove and fills his cup Mary comes up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thanks. (indicating Elaine's  bedroom) I hope we won't be a burden to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope so, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up his coffee and goes out on the porch. Mary  hesitates, then follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLED PAST Clay. Mary comes out. Clay sits on the bench the door, drinking his coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quiet) If you're figuring on asking me to  take you, it's no use.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary crosses to stand above him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A time like this people ought to be  alone. Having us around is going to  make it sort of hard on 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary sighs, sits beside him. From the pocket of her robe takes tobacco, rolls a cigarette and lights it. She passe the tobacco to Clay. He rolls one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on the defensive) I'm sorry, but that's how it's got  to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it's not only because the trip's  a tough one --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary strikes a match and holds the flame to his cigarette

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) You don't have to explain. Did I  tell you how grateful I am for what  you've done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't leave you sitting by the  road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could have treated us like they  did in Aspen. No. You wouldn't do a  thing like that -- it isn't in you  to be mean or cruel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary rises to move to the edge of the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary in f.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) No man who brings up a kid like you've  brought up Steve could ever be cruel  to people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turning, she leans against the post that supports the por

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you get everything you want  out of life --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wary) Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've earned it -- the horse ranch  on the Toulomoe -- the girl in the  spotted gingham.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should know. She's in your dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay puts his cup down, looks up. She is very lovely stan in the moonlight, her body arched back, the robe open a  little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ever since you've looked after Steve  you've had the dream -- a ranch on  the river -- good grass, good water,  barn corral and house --- that part  you've shared with Steve. The girl  in gingham you plan sneakin' in when  he isn't looking. (she pauses)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (enigmatic) Go on. Tell me more about her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wears this gingham dress -- cooks  popovers -- makes jam in season --  makes her own soap from pig fat and  wood ashes and has cheeks the color  of red apples.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dryly) I'll make the soap myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the rest is right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will she be dark or fair?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blonde as a new mop. And beautiful  as the girl on a feed store calendar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Straightening, she crosses the porch to pause momentarily close to Clay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) I hope you find her -- because, like  I said, you've earned your dream.  Goodnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She enters the house. Clay looks after her, smiling faint He knows she is up to something but not what.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT. Save for the moonlight coming through the wind the room is dark. Mary enters softly, throws off her robe and slips into bed beside Helen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on bed. Moonlight falls across the bed. Mary pulls the co up. Helen turns her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you make it interesting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary snuggles down on the pillow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried my best, but these things  take time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we're running out of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's still tomorrow morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. LONG SHOT - ANGLED THROUGH window PAST Mary. The ear morning sun fills the yard. Steve is in the corral harnes the mules. Clay and Wyatt are taking Mary's and Helen's t out of the wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those trunks look like ours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, who was in profile, turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen is seated at the table. Mary stands with her back t the window near the sink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long do you think we'll have to  stay here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until Pa gets around to driving us  to Minden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't want to go there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No we don't. But that's where we're  going. From Minden we take a stage  to Reno, then another one over to  Auburn and another one to Placerville.  Then it's a day's trip to Sonora.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay could save us an awful lot of  time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He certainly could. About a month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you waiting for? Do  something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary comes over to stand by the table. Her expression is  thoughtful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharp) You're not giving up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many ways can a man say no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen rises. Her manner is determined.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crosses to door) Maybe I better start working on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd think he'd do it for Elaine's  sake, at least...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as she stops, apparently inspired by Mary's last remark. looks out into the yard where Clay is working on the wago

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOOTING TOWARD Elaine's bedroom door. Helen crosses to M

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sweetly) If you can't bring him around, nobody  can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts her arm around Mary's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on. Have another try at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the use.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cajoling) Please. Maybe he'll take a good look  at you and stop thinking so much  about his horses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she speaks she edges Mary to the door leading outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man has only so many no's in him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary smiles at her, shrugs and exits. Helen looks after h Mary's footsteps are heard going down the steps. Then Hel swings around and going to Elaine's door, opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT. Elaine is sitting up in bed. There is a small  table by the bed and on it is a breakfast tray. Mrs. Wyat sits by the bed. Elaine looks happy for the first time. M Wyatt is holding a cup to her lips. Helen enters and clos the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at you, sitting up already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crossing to the bed she takes the cup from Mrs. Wyatt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me do this while you get some  breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I like to do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're worn out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she pushes Mrs. Wyatt toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now don't argue. You've got two able- bodied girls to help you so take  advantage of it. And don't let me  catch you touching the dishes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She closes the door behind Mrs. Wyatt and comes back, sit on the edge of the bed and holds the cup to Elaine's lips

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- it's going to be good for  all of us -- having a nice long rest  here. After all -- Sonora will still  be there next month. Maybe we can  rehearse a new number -- try it out  on your folks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine tries not to show her panic at this suggestion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen -- why don't you and Mary go  on with Clay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He won't take us. (then, hurt) Don't you want us around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I do -- but it'd be better  for you -- and the house is kind of  small --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're worried about Mary and me  talkin' too much, don't. No matter  how many questions your old man asks.  We know how to keep our mouths shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't that --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't talk -- eat -- we want to get  you well quick as we can so we can  all get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I want to stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drink this and stop being silly. Why  would anyone want to live in this  place. You might as well be dead and  buried. Nothing to do but look at  mountains. In a week you'd be talking  to yourself. (then, brightly) Maybe that's what got you started in  the first place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine pushes the cup away, sits up straighter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (distraught) I'm not going anywhere. I'm staying  here where I belong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not if I know Mary. When she rides  into Sonora, you'll be with her. And  mighty glad to be there after this.  I don't see how you stood it as long  as you did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sobbing) Stop it -- stop it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (contrite) Darling -- now I've got you all upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine buries her head in the pillow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go away -- please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right -- you go back to sleep.  Tomorrow when you feel better things  will look a whole lot different.  Don't you worry about anything --  Mary's going to talk things over  with your folks --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine sits up and grabs Helen's arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fiercely) She mustn't -- don't you let her --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There, there. Don't you upset yourself --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wildly) If she says anything to them I'll  kill her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and Mrs. Wyatt enters. She hurries over to the bed, pushes Helen aside, and takes the sobbing girl i her arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sobbing) I don't want to leave you, ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Wyatt flares at Helen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you do to her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. The poor child's worried  about Mary --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turning, she goes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't let her say anything --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT. Leaving the door open, Helen enters the kitche She glances back at the bedroom, half smiling, then cross to the window and looks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLED past Helen THROUGH window. Clay is crossing the ya toward the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT. Helen turns from the window and walks hurriedl to the second bedroom door. Clay's footsteps cross the po Helen enters the bedroom and closes the door as Clay come in. Clay looks around, then seeing the open bedroom door, crosses to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLED PAST Clay in doorway. Mrs. Wyatt is holding the so girl in her arms. She looks over at Clay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm off --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then realizing that something is wrong he steps into the  bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled) What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hearing his voice, Elaine lifts her head from her mother' shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't let them stay here, Mr.  Phillips. They'll spoil everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay looks from one to the other, frowning. Elaine tries get out of bed. Her mother holds her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wildly) Take them with you -- Mary's going  to talk to dad -- she's going to  keep talking and talking to me until  maybe I won't want to stay here --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please take them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got to -- don't you understand --  they want me with them and they'll  fix it so I have to go --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharp) No they won't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turning, he exits. Mrs. Wyatt holds Elaine close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT. Helen stands on the porch in the sunlight. She glances back. Clay, his expression hard and angry comes o He doesn't look at Helen but stalks down the steps toward the wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What comes after Z?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the end of the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (happily) Then I know my alphabet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From A to Z. All you have to do now  is figure out what they mean put  together in words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay comes toward the wagon. Helen stands on the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's tough, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without someone to teach you, it's  tough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay appears behind her. Mary turns and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knows his alphabet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll bet I'd be reading in a week if --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He catches Clay's glance and his face falls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe Clay will take up where I left  off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve gets some courage. He comes over to his brother and faces him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think it's fair --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pauses; Clay waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leaving them here when we could just  as well take them. We got plenty of  room in the wagon. And -- and --  they cook and drive the mules. They  don't bother anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finished, son?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weakly) There's only two of them now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay moves past them toward the corral. Mary looks after  him, then turning, motions to Helen. Helen starts toward wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay's horse stands saddled at the fence. He vaults into saddle, turns the horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll round up the horses. Throw that  junk in the wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rides off. Steve, delighted, runs to start loading the girls' things. Helen hurries into the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary and Helen. Mary smiles at Helen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (happily) You were right -- a man has only so  many no's in him. But he had me  worried -- that last one sounded so  final.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen nods, looking at Mary as though in admiration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT - the wagon, followed by the remuda and with Cl riding ahead moves slowly up the canyon back of the ranch

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT - ANGLED WEST. The forest is fairly open, yello pine, lodgepole and fir. To the West can be seen the bald red granite domes of the higher range. O.s. there is the  SOUND of the cavalcade approaching. CAMERA PANS AROUND an ANGLES PAST. Toward camera, comes the cavalcade, climbing slowly. Far in the distance and down can be seen the wast of desert and the barren hills of Nevada. Clay, a rifle a his legs, is riding on one side of the wagon. Steve rides beside Mary, who is driving. The remuda trails behind. He lying in the wagon bed, cannot be seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLED PAST Steve. Steve has a copy of Leslie's Weekly op on the pommel. Helen lies full length in the wagon bed,  occupying herself by giving herself a manicure with an or stick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a lot tougher than I figured.  Knowin' my letters is one thing. But  makin' sense out of words is harder'n  trackin' weasel after rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay glances over at his brother. Mary sees him watching. Their eyes meet. She smiles. He doesn't return the smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and even if I do learn to read,  what use'll it be? I'm goin' to live  on a ranch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's plenty of use for reading --  you'll see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sighs and scowls down at the page. He puts his finger a word and starts to spell it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: U-n-i-c-o-r-n-... What in heck's  that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unicorn -- a kind of animal --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do they look like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmm... sort of like a horse -- with  a horn in the center of its forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Horses with horns! Huh! Do we have  'em in Nevada?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about California?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would they be good to eat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not too sure) Kind of tough, I guess... But you're  not liable to hunt them -- I don't  think there's any alive now, anyways --  and I'm not sure but I don't think  there ever were...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then if they wasn't alive, how can  they be an animal?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary starts to protest -- Steve goes on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An' if you can't hunt 'em and even  if you could they'd be tough, what's  the use of knowin' how to spell them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't read to fill your stomach...  Poetry, for instance. All the poems  in the world wouldn't fill you half  as much as a bowl of eatmeal -- but  they make you feel good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stubbornly) I feel good anyways.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLED PAST Clay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't go arguing with your teacher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not, but there's some of it I  don't see any sense to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a lot of things I don't see  any sense to. But make up your mind.  Learn to read or -- (motioning) -- go back and watch the horses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He touches his horse with his spurs and rides on ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLED PAST Mary. Steve in the b.g. Mary looks after Clay puzzled, wondering. Then she looks over at Steve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Steve?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning) Now I know what a unicorn is, what  do we do next?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here the forest has thinned out. The trail climbs a rise, then drops down. Clay jogs along the trail, his rifle acr his knees. As he reaches the edge of the forest at the cr of the rise, he suddenly pulls his horse to a stop, swing around and rides back into the trees. Throwing the reins  over the horse's head, he swings out of the saddle and mo cautiously to the crest of the hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay's ANGLE. The trail leads down through open country t big meadow ringed with lodgepole pine, and across the mea to start climbing toward another, higher range of hills.  Three horsemen on roans, Lednov, Peters and McCall, are  crossing the meadow slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOWN ANGLE. Lednov, Peters and McCall as they ride across the meadow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay, as he peers down. He cocks his rifle. The voices of Mary and Steve and the SOUND of the approaching wagon can heard o.s. Clay turns his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the cavalcade. Mary and Helen are in the seat of the wago Steve rides alongside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay. He lowers his rifle, waves at them to stop and be q rises and hurries down the hill, CAMERA PANNING WITH him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT of Lednov as he pulls in his limping horse, ste looking back over his shoulder as though he sensed an  unfamiliar presence. The other two watch him, frowning. T he shrugs and glances down at the bad leg of his mount.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll camp on up ahead away. That  leg ain't good...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they start away, moving slowly toward the trees in the distance...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay motions to Mary to stop as he hurries toward the wag Mary reins in the mules.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're staying here until dark. (motioning) Pull over to the woods. (to Steve) You put hobbles on the horses -- all  of 'em. Get goin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT. Clay, in close foreground, stands, leaning on rifle. The sun has set and the valley below is in shadow. There is the silence of dusk. No wind stirs the trees. Th is some light outlining the high mountains -- treeless cr and domes and spires. Clay turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down the hill in the forest, is the wagon. Beyond it the  horses stand. Steve is stretched out on his stomach study his magazine. Helen is sitting on a tarp playing solitair Clay starts down the hill toward the camp.

dialogues.speaker: UP ANGLE
dialogues.text: Clay walks through the trees. As he comes around a big ye pine, he stops suddenly and looks down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLED DOWN PAST Clay. Mary lies on the carpet of pine  needles, her head pillowed on her arms, her dress pulled  taut across her chest. She is looking up through the tree at the fading sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay stares down at Mary. She does not look at him. She i aware of his presence, but she doesn't show it. In the so light of dusk she is very lovely. Clay is conscious of he lovliness. He would like to drop down beside her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary. She turns her face to look at him. CAMERA ANGLE WID Clay stands above her, looking down. For a moment their e meet. Clay starts away. CAMERA HOLDS ON Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you goin'? Over to the other  side of the street?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLED PAST Mary, who rises slowly. Clay looks back,  hesitates, then crosses to where the horses are tethered starts saddling his mare. Mary moves down toward him thro the trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay tightens the cinch. Mary moves up to stand beside hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we leaving?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's too light yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He swings into the saddle, pulls the rifle out of the sca and lays it across the pommel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better go on back and get some more  sleep. You'll need it later on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (soberly) You're not going out to look for  them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm not. All I want 'em to do is  keep ahead of us -- a long way ahead.  So I'm riding up the line aways to  pick us out a new trail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He touches the mare with his spurs and trots down the hil He disappears around a bend in the trail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, in the f.g., is staring after Clay. Helen is watchi her. Steve has risen and walks up behind her. He smiles a her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody's gonna catch him sleeping.  Don't worry about him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning) Oh, I wasn't worrying. (flustered) I saw him saddling up and thought he  was ready to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts down toward the wagon, Steve walking beside he and CAMERA TRUCKING WITH them THROUGH the forest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) You were worryin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary glances over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes not knowin' how to read  has its points. You can't read books  so you look at people and figure 'em  out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you've got me all figured out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have passed Helen, playing solitaire on the canvas, have reached the place where the grub box stands. Steve  spreads a tarp for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll fix us somethin' to eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary sits down. Steve opens the grub box and takes out so plates, tinned food and hardtack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like when you were standin' there  looking after Clay. I knew right off  what you were thinking. Because I've  been watching you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were supposed to be reading words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was doin' both. Here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands her a plate of food, takes another and goes over Helen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen looks up from her card game, takes the plate with a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Steve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grins at her, turns and comes back to Mary who is watc him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better not let Clay catch you waitin'  on us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve sits on the edge of the grub box and picks up his p

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't pay any attention to him. That's  his way and I've found he's sure  easy to get along with. I don't  recollect him havin' hit me more'n a  couple of times and I guess I had it  comin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're his brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll treat his wife just as good.  Maybe better. Ever see him use a  bull snake on the mules like other  wranglers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir, Clay's nice to be around. (the clincher) He don't chew much and when he does  he spits outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dryly) You make him sound wonderful... Go  on. Tell Mary more about him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve looks over at her, embarrassed, a little hurt by he tone. He rises, takes Mary's empty plate and his own and  goes over to the little spring to wash them. Mary looks  sharply at Helen. Helen shrugs. Mary rises and follows St over to the spring.

dialogues.speaker: SPRING
dialogues.text: Steve kneels by the little pool, washing the plates in th run off. Mary stops above him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was only teasin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (offhand) Oh, sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She kneels beside him. Steve looks over at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like to do things for you. Didn't  you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks down at the water bubbling up into the little m lined pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) I know now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT - DOWN ANGLE. O.s. there is the SOUND of the  cavalcade moving. A wheel passes camera, then another. CA PULLS BACK to reveal the wagon passing in the moonlit  darkness. Mary is driving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay rides into the shot, his rifle ready. The wagon foll Then the remuda with Steve bringing up the rear. Steve al holds his rifle ready. Both men are wary, watchful,  apprehensive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT - DOWN ANGLE. SHOOTING DOWN THROUGH the leaves a quaking aspen. The cavalcade moves on along the trail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT. The east is grey with the approaching dawn. Th terrain is treeless, forbidding. Granite crags rise all  around. The trail leads up through a canyon then narrows  along the edge of a cliff. The cavalcade toils forward. C in the lead, stops and waits for the wagon to come abreas

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the wagon comes abreast, Clay dismounts, loops the rei over the tail gate, then swings up into the seat, motioni for Mary to move over. He takes the reins, puts his rifle down in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: MOVING, (PROCESS)
dialogues.text: Clay and Mary. Helen is sleeping in the bed of the wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you trust me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not on this trail, I don't. I've  been over it before. Anyway, you  ought to be pretty sleepy. Why don't  you climb in back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary glances ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like to see where I'm going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She picks up the rifle and holds it across her knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dryly) Did you ever care where you were  goin' or where you'd been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary glances over at him wonderingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe not! But I want to get there  in one piece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ride along in silence for a moment. The trail is rou The jolting wagon throws them together. Their shoulders t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Why did you change your mind about  bringing us along?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (soberly) I don't know. I thought I did. Now  I'm not sure. I thought it had  something to do with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it did. It had a great deal to  do with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary studies him, trying to figure out what he means.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just how do you mean that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay is busy with driving down the rough road. He speaks  without looking at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know so much about me -- figure  it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So that's it -- (he glances over) You think I was making fun of your  girl in gingham.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen. She lies in the bed of the wagon, looking up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't. And I wasn't making fun of  you or your dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She waits for an answer, but getting none, continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, maybe I was trying to get  you to do something you didn't want  to do.

dialogues.speaker: MOVING, (PROCESS)
dialogues.text: Clay and Mary. Clay busies himself with the brake and the reins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't do a thing like that,  would you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Yes. But -- that was the other night.  Now -- I don't think I would.

dialogues.speaker: ANGLED AHEAD
dialogues.text: Clay and Mary in f.g. The trail now goes down a slope to river, which boils out of a narrow canyon, then follows t river through the canyon. Clay hands the reins to Mary, t his rifle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the West Walker. Take it easy  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay swings down. The wagon moves past him. He frees his  horse, swings into the saddle and gallops down toward the canyon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary. She looks after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wagon moves down toward the river. Clay disappears in the canyon. Steve and the remuda follow the wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLED TOWARD mouth of canyon. Clay rides along the trail his rifle at the ready. Now he moves warily, keeping a sh lookout. The canyon is dark, sinister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cavalcade enters the canyon.

dialogues.speaker: SHOOTING DOWN
dialogues.text: Clay rides toward camera. The trail curves around a cliff

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay. He rides around the bend in the trail. He hears  something. He reins the horse in. Some pebbles rattle dow the cliff. He looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The muzzle of a rifle is visible. Clay starts to bring hi gun up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay lets his rifle rest across his knees. He looks up.  Fowler, a well-set-up young man in jeans, blue shirt and  worn jacket and wearing a battered hat, moves into scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay. He is wary, puzzled as to the man's identity. For a he knows it may be one of Lednov's men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay and Fowler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doin' on this trail?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Followin' it. Any reason I shouldn't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOOTING PAST Fowler. Into view comes the wagon and the  remuda. Fowler lowers his rifle. He slides down the cliff stand beside Clay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay and Fowler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name's Fowler. I'm camped up a  ways.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He extends his hand. Clay shakes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay Phillips of Aspen. Been havin'  trouble?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope. But I don't want any.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither do we. That's why we took  this trail instead of the main road,  and drove all night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're welcome to use my camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He motions ahead, starts walking. Clay rides beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT. The river is beyond the meadow. In the pine fo at the edge of the meadow is Fowler's camp. The cavalcade driving up to the camp. There are two horses tethered in meadow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. FULL SHOT. A tarp is stretched over the camp. There a crude stone fireplace, a rough table and two benches.  Shelves are nailed between the trees. In a small lean-to  there is a bunk with Fowler's bedroll on it. Fowler stand watching Mary and Holen as they get out of the wagon. The horses sproad out across the meadow. Steve and Clay dismo Both unsaddle. Helen, Mary and Fowler exchange glances. T the two women walk toward the camp, which is behind a scr of trees.

dialogues.speaker: CAMP
dialogues.text: Helen and Mary enter the camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We might as well start a fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead. (nodding off) Get in training for the pioneer life.  I'm finding the nearest body of water  and climbing into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes off and across the meadow. Mary looks after her, shrugs and going to the fireplace, takes moss and twigs f the pile and puts them in. Clay, carrying saddle bags and canteens, enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got a light?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts them down, goes over to the fireplace and kneels light the moss. Mary has stepped back.

dialogues.speaker: LOW
dialogues.text: As he lights the fire, the lower portion of Mary's body c into the shot. Clay becomes aware of her closeness. He ri slowly. CAMERA ANGLES UP. Mary is standing facing him, al touching him. They stare at each other without speaking.  Both suddenly move togother. They kiss. There is a SOUND  over shot and they step apart, looking off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve has come into scene and is looking at them. He smil with pleasure and surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (innocently) Want the wagon unloaded, Clay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (upset) Just the grub box and bed rolls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve nods, smiles at both of them and goes out of scene. Clay and Mary face each other. Suddenly Clay swings aroun and goes out of shot after his brother.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: She looks after him, clearly in love, disappointed that t were interrupted. Then she turns to the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay and Steve. CAMERA MOVES AHEAD of them as they walk t the wagon. Steve has begun to whistle blithely. Clay look sideways at him. Steve whistles even louder. They stop at the wagon. CAMERA HOLDS. Steve climbs inside and hands do the grub box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I -- I think it'll be swell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay puts the grub box on the ground. Steve tosses out th bed rolls, then jumps out. He grins up at Clay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay, embarrassed, puts his hand on the boy's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you get older you'll understand  things better. Like women and men.  Just because a man kisses a woman,  doesn't always mean -- well, he can  kiss her and not want to -- have her  around all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve watches him, puzzled. His exuberance has gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got a lot to do, you and I. Gettin'  that ranch started and everything.  We've been getting along fine, all  these years. For a while I want to  keep it the way it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abruptly Clay turns and indicates the grub box. Steve wat him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take that in and help her get  breakfast, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve nods and carries the grub box out of the scene. Cla stares after him. Then he picks up the bed roll and moves around the wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay in the f.g. In front of Clay stretches the meadow wi the river beyond. The horses are grazing in the meadow. F can be seen hurrying toward the aspens and alders that sc the river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT. Here the river moves quietly down. The bank is sandy. Alders and aspens screen it from the meadow. Helen sits on the sand taking off her shoes and stockings. Her  toilet box is beside her. Something on the bank catches h attention, she rises and climbs the bank. Some branches o aspen cover an object. She pulls the branches away, revea a crud, miner's cradle or rocker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen stares down at the cradle. She doesn't know what it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharp) What are you doing down here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen, startled, turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fowler and Helen. They stare at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (curt) You got no business snoopin' around --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hard) Me snoopin'? I came down here to  take a bath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She glances from Fowler to the cradle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That something I shouldn't see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flustered) No. But it's mine and I didn't want  anyone foolin' with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurriedly he covers it with branches again. Helen watches him, curious, interested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a thing I was workin' on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The way you act, it must be something  pretty secret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Fowler doesn't explain she moves on down the bank an sits on the sand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on. Take your bath. I'll beat it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't have a smoke on you,  would you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fowler comes over and sits down beside her. He takes [a]  sack of tobacco and papers from his pocket. She reaches f them. He watches her wide-eyed as she rolls a cigarette. holds a match for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns to the toilet case on the sand beside her, take out a comb. He glances at the box, then reaches over and  from it takes her powder box. He sniffs it. Without  irritation, as though borrowing a toy from a child, Helen takes the powder box from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That sure smells good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up here in the hills, a man gets a  hankering to smell powder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why stay in the hills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him then up the bank where the cradle is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fowler hesitates. Helen hands him back the powder box as  matter-of-factly as she took it. He accepts it gratefully again putting it to his nose. Now he looks up at her,  regarding her calculatingly for a moment or two. Their ey meet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess you can keep a secret. That's  a gold rocker. I'm doin' a little  placer mining in a place nobody ever  thought to look for gold before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches to his throat and lifts over his head a braide loop of rawhide. Attached to the loop is a small, plump,  soft-leather poke. Still holding the powder box, he passe her the poke. She starts to work with the thong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at her -- see her shine. One  week's work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen still struggles with the thong. He takes the poke,  pulls it open, pouring grains of gold into his palm. Hele looks at the shining heap in his hand. Then she takes the poke and pours some of the grains in her own palm. She lo down at it. Her expression is calculating. She looks up a Fowler and then the hard look goes away. She gives him a  soft smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT - DOWN ANGLE. Mary is asleep in the shade of a pine. She lies on a tarp using a folded blanket for a pil It is very quiet. She stirs, opens her eyes. Her expressi changes. A soft smile plays around her lips as CAMERA ANG WIDENS and we see Clay sitting near her, leaning against bole of a pine. He isn't looking at her. Mary watches him for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Roll me a cigarette, Clay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay looks over at her. Then rising he moves closer, squa and rolls a cigarette. He holds it out. She licks it, the puts it in her mouth. Clay lights a match, holds it out. catches his hand and holds the flame to her cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She still holds his hand. They look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you wake me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should have. I don't like leaving  things unfinished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quiet) Maybe it's better that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (intense) You don't mean that Clay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She holds his hand, smiling up. Clay hesitates, then desi for her is more than he can bear, so he takes her in his  arms. They kiss, holding the kiss for a long while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They break. She lies looking up. He half lies, half sits  beside her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a whisper) Tell me, darling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does a man usually tell a girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For answer, Clay kisses her again -- hard, ruthlessly. Hi hands crush her shoulders. Mary holds the kiss for a mome then draws back, waiting for him to say the words she wan to hear. His hands pull her toward him. Mary wants the ki but she also wants a declaration of love. She makes one l try to get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me -- please --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay's grip on her shoulders tightens. She searches his f with a glance -- stares into his eyes -- then pushes him  away and sits up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary. She is hurt by his silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right you don't love me. So let  it go at that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA ANGLE WIDENS. Clay's expression hardens. He drops hands from her shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you expect? Speeches I don't  mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't expect anything. A minute  ago I hadn't cuite waked up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stands. He rises to face her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm awake now. Go on. Say what you  want to say. I'll listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it's pretty speeches you want,  you won't be hearing them. Even when  I mean 'em, they don't come easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Save 'em for the girl in gingham.  Just tell me I'm not good enough for  you. Go on. Say a woman like me can't  change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right -- it's said!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then let's get started. The sooner I  get to Sonora, the better I'll like  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turning she starts down toward camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLED PAST Clay. Below is the camp. Beyond the camp, thr the trees, stands the wagon and Steve is hitching up the  mules. Clay hesitates, then follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary. Tears form in her eyes. She blinks them away, compo herself with an effort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT - Helen and Fowler in f.g. Helen sits at one si of the table, Fowler on the other. Helen holds the soft  leather poke. In the b.g. Mary approaches. Behind her com Clay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're sure there's more where this  came from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plenty more. (motioning) And somewhere up there's the lode,  the rock rotten with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen pours the gold out in her palm as Mary comes up. Ma stands looking down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty, isn't it? And all you have  to do is shovel sand into a thing  and the river does the work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay enters the scene and goes over to pick up his saddle bags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quiet) Give it back to him. We're leavin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you are. I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reaches over and pats Fowler's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm stayin' here with Jed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary looks from Helen to Fowler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shyly) I figure we'll get along just fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well cheer, why don't you? No more  responsibilities, Mary. Marcia --  Elaine -- me -- all taken care of.  Down there feeding horses and raising  kids, you won't have a thing to worry  about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary stands looking down at Helen. Lovingly Helen pours t gold back in the poke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not raising horses or kids for  anybody. I'm opening the slickest  gambling house in California with a  crystal chandelier, the biggest you  ever saw --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay, saddle bags in hand, straightens. Mary directs the  rest of the speech at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Gaslights and a dance floor and a  big bar. Cash registers with bells  and a couple of boys with armbands  just to keep 'em ringing. What do  you think of that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds fine. Only that isn't how  it's going to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen juggles the poke in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure of this. But not of you. (shakes head) You won't open any joint. I've been  watching you change. You're mad now  and you think you can change back.  But you can't. You'll end up making  beds in a boarding house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (furious) That's it then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the master) That's it. She's staying with me --  for keeps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
