dialogues.text: Steve has entered the camp and is standing looking at the open-mouthed. Mary moves over to Fowler and holds out her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there were more men like you,  there wouldn't be so many of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nice to meet a man who doesn't  want to own a woman from the day she  was born. I never had the luck. The  only kind I've run into were tramps  or dirty-minded hypocrites.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay moves up beside Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay, Mary and Fowler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Fowler) She's aimin' at me, but her aim's  bad. (to Mary) Want to know why I changed my mind  about bringing you? Because I talked  to Elaine -- because I was afraid to  leave you with decent people, that's  why. And you'll open your joint all  right. You wouldn't fit anywhere  else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves on past her, motions to Steve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's round up the horses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharp) Come on -- we don't want to keep the  people in Sonora waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stalks away, followed by Steve. Mary turns and looks a him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary. She wants to break windows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, Fowler and Helen. Helen is staring at Mary. She cro to her and puts her arm around her shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, Honey. I talked too much, like  always -- he thinks you told Elaine  the things I told her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (furious) I don't care what he thinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary throws her arm off and moves after Clay and Steve. H looks at Fowler and shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the wagon. As Mary hurries up to stand by the tail gate,  Clay and Steve, now mounted, spur their horses and start  across the meadow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary. She stares after them, raging. Then she glances at wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary in f.g. The mulos stand in their traces, waiting. Ma makes up her mind what to do. Climbing into the bed, she  heaves out pack saddles, bed rolls, ropes, etc. Clay and  Stove can be seen in b.g. riding down toward where the ho graze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLED TOWARD camp. Into the scene come pack saddles, bed rolls. Helen and Fowler, in b.g., walk toward the wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: wagon. Mary straightens, looks off, then climbs into the  seat and picks up the reins and the whip. She lashes the  mules with the whip. CAMERA ANGLE WIDENS. The mules jump gallop off. Fowler and Helen come into the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the wagon, pulled by the galloping mules, is disappearing a cloud of dust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the meadow. Clay and Steve have almost reached the horses Steve turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay -- look!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay swings around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: their ANGLE. Mary drives the wagon around a bend in the t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON Clay. He glances after Mary, then reins his horse arou and gallops after her, CAMERA PANNING WITH him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVING SHOT. Mary drives the wagon along the trail. Ahead beyond the river, the mountains rise. The river is runnin bank full. The trail leads down to a rocky, dangerous ban Mary pulls the mules in at the bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary. She looks toward the river. She is frightened, abou to abandon the whole foolish enterprise. She glances back

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FROM Mary's ANGLE. Clay gallops around a bend in the trai

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary. She looks in Clay's direction, then turns and stare at the river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLED PAST Mary. She makes up her mind to go through wit it and lashes the mules with the whip. CAMERA ANGLE WIDEN The mules balk when they reach the river. Mary lashes the again. They jump forward into the torrent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay gallops toward the river. Steve comes around the ben in the trail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the river. The mules flounder, start swimming. The curren catches the wagon. It starts drifting downstream. Mary wh the mules. They swim, the current pulls them. Then the wa goes over. Mary is thrown into the water. The mules kick  themselves free and swim to the other bank. Mary goes und comes up and starts swimming desperately. Clay rides into the SHOT. His mare hesitates at the bank. Clay spurs her she plunges in. Mary's belongings can be seen floating do the river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay swims his horse toward Mary who is floundering in th stream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary. The current sweeps her against a rock. Stunned -- s goes under.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay swims his horse to her, reaches down and lifts her u in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay's horse, with the double burden, fights her way out the stream and scrambles up the bank to stop on level gro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay and Mary. Clay, his expression anxious, stares down the stunned Mary. He swings out of the saddle, holding he tenderly to him. The brush with death has made him realiz how much she means to him. Gently, he puts her down on th sand, stoops beside her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay and Mary in f.g. Steve swims his horse across and ri up the bank to dismount near them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary --

dialogues.speaker: DOWN ANGLE
dialogues.text: Mary opens her eyes and sits up

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (anxiously) Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary is humiliated, bedraggled and wet, still angry and  fighting back tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharp) No, I'm not all right. I'm soaked  and I hit myself against that rock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nettlod at her tone) I suppose that's my fault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary gets to her feet. CAMERA ANGLE WIDENS. Steve stands the b.g. She looks out at the river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wailing) All my clothes --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right -- worry about your  clothes --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: to include wagon in river. Clay, suddenly furious, points the wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about my wagon. Of all the crazy  fool things to do. You lose a man's  wagon because you're stupid and then  yell about your clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the last straw. Mary turns her back, digs into he stocking and pulls out some bills. She hands them to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay looks at Mary, then down at the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, take it. Then you can't spend  the rest of the trip expecting to  get paid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (furious) There won't be any rest of the trip.  Over the hill is a stage road and  when we hit it you get dumped into  the first stage that comes along. So  keep your money. You'll need it for  the fare. I'm fed up with you. I was  fed up with you before we started.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and sees Steve standing scowling at him. He take the rest of his anger out on Steve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't just stand there. Go on back  and get the packs on the horses.  We've lost all the time we're going  to because of a woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay strides over to his horse and swings into the saddle Steve stands looking at Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. Didn't you hear me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he plunges his horse into the stream:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT - the lower ford. Where the main road crosses t river, it flows gently, with sand banks on either side. T horsemen appear around a bend in the trail and ride down the riverbank. They are Lednov, McCall and Peters. Lednov horse is limping badly. They ride into the river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The horses swim to shore and flounder up the bank, Lednov horse last. As the horse starts up the bank Lednov sees  something o.s. and reins the horse in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FROM Lednov's ANGLE. A piece of clothing floats down the  river. Lednov rides down the bank into the water. He reac down awkwardly and gets the piece of clothing, then turns and rides back up the bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two others have turned and are watching him. He rides to them, holding out one of Mary's undergarments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got company. Female company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at the garment) Yeah, we sure have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to scan the river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary's trunk comes floating by. The three men look at eac other, then Lednov turns his horse and starts up the bank the river. The others follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXTREME LONG SHOT. The long pine-covered approaches, and glistening summit; the early snow covering the rocks with thin layer of white. CAMERA PANS DOWN FROM the heights of the mountains, TO the narrow trail that winds among the t Clay passes, and behind him the pack-horses and the romud Following the remuda comes Mary. She is dressed in a pair Steve's pants and wears one of his shirts under her own c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, as she swings with the movement of the horse. She i tired. She wears no makeup. But she looks as unaffectedly beautiful as we have ever seen her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the trail. It turns steeply, doubling back, and new Clay directly above her. He looks down at her, but she disrega his glance. We feel that he might speak, but her cold  restraint prevents him. The wind whistles through the tre The slow plodding noise of the horses becomes more distan

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. FULL SHOT. Lednov, McCall and Peters ride slowly thr the brush to where the trail enters the river. Downstream wedged in the rocks is the wagon. The three men look at t wagon, then turn to look back along the trail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: their ANGLE. Fowler's campfire flickers through the trees

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the three men. They look at each other. Lednov motions in the direction of Fowler's camp. They start back along the trail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT. The three men ride along the trail toward the  camp. Through the trees the campfire flickers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT. Fowler is putting the supper dishes up on the  shelves beside the fireplace. The camp is cleaner than it was earlier in the day. It is evident that he has gone to great pains to make his visitor comfortable. A mirror has been tacked up on a tree, and under it is a  wash basin. Fowler's rifle and shotgun are in a rack near the fireplace. Helen's trunk stands open near the lean-to Helen, wearing a robe, takes some clothing from it, close the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can put this out of the way,  Jed. It's empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fowler turns and smiles. Helen pushes through the curtain into the lean-to. Fowler puts the last of the dishes on t shelf, crosses to the trunk and moves it over to the side the lean-to. Turning to go back to the fireplace, he stop

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fowler in the f.g. Lednov, rifle in hand, stands just ins the camp on the meadow side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning slowly) What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lednov moves slowly forward to stand near the table. He l around him. Fowler starts slowly toward the fireplace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw your fire and dropped by to  say hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, say it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trying to be casual, Fowler moves closer to where the gun are racked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter -- restless?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, people make me restless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even women?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There aren't any women here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose that's your wagon in the  river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some people who went by this way  lost it. (nervously) Two men and some women. They packed  their stuff on horses and went on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're all alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has edged closer to the gun rack. Lednov seems unaware that he is near the guns. His interest is centered on the lean-to. He moves to the entrance, stands with his hand o the canvas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suppose I take a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lednov pulls back the flap. His back is to Fowler, who st quickly for the tree, only to stop as McCall comes out fr behind it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking for something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fowler drops his hands to his side. Lednov turns, grins a Fowler, and enters the lean-to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shelter is dark. Lednov strikes a match and looks aro The place is empty. There is a bunk, made up. On the left hand wall a curtain of gunny sacks covers the clothes han there. The match burns down to Lednov's fingers. There is SOUND of a scuffle outside a blow, and a groan. Lednov dr the match and hurries out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lednov comes out of the lean-to. Fowler is sprawled by th table. McCall stands over him, rifle raised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold it, Mac.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. CLOSE SHOT. Helen stands flattened against a tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cautiously Helen starts moving away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT. Fowler pulls himself to his feet. Mac stands n him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. Where'd the women go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fowler sinks on a bench, his head in his hands. Lednov mo closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I ask questions, I like to hear  answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They went on like I told you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT. Helen cautiously moves away from the camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long ago?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five, six hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A twig snaps underfoot. Helen freezes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT. Lednov is staring off in the direction of Hele McCall moves to the edge of the lean-to, looking off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. CLOSE SHOT. Helen starts forward again, more cautiou than ever. She reaches a tree, turns to look back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen, back to camera, is in immediate f.g. Through the t can be seen the camp and the flickering fire. She turns, then fright comes into her expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peters stands in front of her. As he reaches out for her, she tries to get away. He grabs her, wrapping his arms ar her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT. From o.s. comes the SOUND of Helen and Peters  struggling. Fowler, hearing the SOUND, gets to his feet.  Lednov and McCall turn on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down. (calling) All right, Peters, come on over here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT. Peters, carrying the struggling Helen, heads f the camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANOTHER ANGLE. Fowler makes a futile dive for Lednov. McC swings his rifle. Fowler goes down. In the b.g. Peters dr the struggling Helen around the lean-to into the camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Fowler) So you were all alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves forward to meet Helen and Peters. Lednov reaches out for Helen. Peters pulls her away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharp) You keep your hands off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCall has taken his attention from Fowler and gives it t Helen. Unnoticed now, Fowler is struggling back to  consciousness. He tries to pull himself up. McCall turns  back and kicks him again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling) Let him alone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She rakes Peters' face with her fingernails, tries to fig free. Lednov reaches out and grabs her arm. Peters knocks his arm down. Free for the moment, Helen launches an atta on McCall, who is getting ready to boot Fowler again. She on him like a cat, swarming all over him. He defends hims Helen is yelling furiously as she fights McCall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kick a guy, would you! You scum! You  won't do any kickin' when they come  back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lednov has reached her now. He wraps his arms around her pulls her away from McCall. Helen tries to fight him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You dirty murderers... killin' people  when they're sleepin'...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lednov pinions her arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know who we are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody knows --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excited) Who brought you here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen doesn't answer. Lednov starts twisting her arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said somebody was comin' back --  who's comin' back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moaning) Stop it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the pain increases she blurts out Clay's name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay Phillips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up the trail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a fury, Lednov crushes her arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How far up the trail?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moaning) I don't know -- I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hurls her from him. She goes back against the table. F is trying to struggle to his feet. In blind rage, Lednov  raises his gun and fires. Fowler crumples. Helen looks do too horrified and terrified to scream. Lednov looks at he then almost casually he shoots her. McCall and Peters sta watching as though frozen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (huskily) You didn't have to do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deadly) Why not? She might have got to Clay  Phillips before I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. FULL SHOT - ANGLES east. Behind the ridge rises the  range through which the pass to Nevada cuts its way. The  trail which has dipped down into a canyon comes up to fol the ridge a ways and then drops down again. Lednov, McCal and Peters ride along the trail. Lednov, in the lead, sto suddenly and looks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOWN ANGLE from Lednov's point of view. Far below is a me and crossing it is a wagon road. This is the road from  Yosemite to Sonora. The road comes down the hill to the s and, as the forest is open at this point, anything approa along the road can be seen for some distance. It crosses meadow and continues into the northwest. In the meadow is snake-rail corral. Clay's pack train comes out of the woo above the meadow and starts down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCall, Lednov and Peters. Lednov motions to his men and  they hurriedly ride forward into the shelter of some tree

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the pack train. Mary, half asleep, slumps forward. Her ho has stopped. Steve rides up alongside and looks over at h anxiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary starts into wakefulness. She smiles at Steve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the last ten miles I've been  trying to figure out how to sleep  sitting up. I'm getting to the point  where I don't think there's any place  named Sonora.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a long ways yet. (arrogantly, to Clay) I figure we ought to camp. She's  tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So am I and so are the horses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rides on ahead. Steve looks after him, annoyed, then  follows with Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay leads the pack train out into the clearing and towar the road. A small creek threads its way through the meado Clay rides up to the creek and swings out of the saddle. is taking the saddle off as the others ride up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Steve) Take the packs off. And run the horses  into the corral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He throws the saddle down, takes his rifle out of the  scabbard. Steve doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said take the packs off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts off past Mary, glances up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary leans wearily forward on the pommel, too tired to  dismount.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gruffly) I figure we'll make better time,  letting the horses rest for a spell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary looks down at him. She is hoping he will reach up an lift her down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So grab yourself some sleep while  you have the chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you want to go on, I can make it  all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like I said, I was thinkin' of the  horses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns a way abruptly and goes toward the road. Mary lo after him, disappointed. Steve comes over and helps her d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve and Mary. Steve spreads a tarp on the grass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You stretch out. I'll fix something  to eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sitting) Thanks, Steve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve goes back and starts unpacking the horses. Mary loo off in Clay's direction, then stretches out and pillows h head on her arm. Now the sun is coming up and driving the darkness out of the meadow. In the distance Clay can be s climbing up on a rise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay. He climbs up on an eminence and looks back toward t hills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: his ANGLE. The open ridge. There is no sign of Lednov.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTO the meadow. Steve has unpacked the horses. They graz inside the crude corral. Steve is collecting wood for a f Clay hurries down toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve squats beside the pile of needles, twigs and pine c He strikes a match and sets the needles aflame. Clay hurr into the scene and roughly kicks the fire out. Steve rise

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) If you want 'em to find us, why don't  you go up on the hill and wave your  shirt or fire your rifle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve is ashamed of his thoughtlessness and for a moment apologetic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't stop to think, Clay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (short) You better start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay turns and goes over to where the packs lie. He kneel beside the pack, rummages in them for hardtack and tinned food. Steve looks after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve. He is hurt and angry. Knowing he was in the wrong  about the fire doesn't help matters. He'd like to go off the woods and cry, but that's out of the question. Instea he follows Clay and stands above him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you and me better split up  when we hit Sonora.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay speaks without looking up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mildly) All right, I hurt your feelings. But  you know better than to go lightin'  fires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That ain't why. I just figure it's  about time to start runnin' my own  life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay spreads the food on a tarp, sits down and starts eat a hardtack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you're not hungry, but I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve stares down at him angrier, more hurt than ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. We got a couple hours to  eat and get some sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll eat when I'm good and ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kind of feeling your oats this  morning. I haven't laid a hand on  you for quite a while, but that  doesn't mean you're too old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes you think you're so  almighty? Telling people what to do  and how to act when you don't even  know how yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [As this scene continues, there is heard, faintly o.s. th SOUND of little bells, the kind that teamsters put on the hames of their horses. Over the hill, in the direction of Yosemite, a stage is approaching. It is coming slowly uph Soon it will be visible on the rise about a mile south of the meadow.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOOTING TOWARD Steve and Clay PAST Mary. She is asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't even man enough to own up  when you're wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay rises and stands facing Steve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, hit me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down and eat. Till I say the  word, you're doing what you're told.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You oughta say you're sorry -- that's  what you oughta do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You keep your nose out of my life,  young fella.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I haven't lived as long as you  have, but I know a sight more about  people and I wouldn't talk to a mule  like you talked to her and, if I  did, I'd say how sorry I was. I'd be  man enough to do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve's voice rises during this speech. In f.g. Mary stir and opens her eyes. Then she sits up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said keep your nose out of my life.  No kid is going to tell me how to  run it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think you're so slmighty -- smart --  Who are you to sit up there and say  nobody's good enough for you, like  you said yesterday -- just because a  man kisses a woman --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary has risen. She is listening to Steve. She is also  listening to the bells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: her ANGLE. Over the rise comes the stage. It is still a l way off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- doesn't mean he wants to marry  her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: to include all three. The brothers still don't see Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if you didn't mean it, why did  you kiss her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay is ashamed but won't show it. He puts his hand on St shoulder and pushes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up and eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve swings for his chin. Clay ducks the blow, grabs Ste wrist. Steve swings with his left, hitting Clay ineffectu Clay pins Steve's arms to his side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply) Stop it -- both of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks toward them as Clay releases Steve and steps ba Steve puts his hands up, making ready for another round.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't have you fighting over me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Steve) I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know what it is to be sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharp) Steve --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve turns abruptly and moves away. He is on the verge o tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Clay) Mind sortin' out my things -- I'm  leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She motions off. Clay is suddenly aware of the approachin stage. He looks in that direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FROM his ANGLE. The stage drives along the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it isn't going to Sonora, but  it's going somewhere, which is all  right with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's going to Sonora.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine -- maybe I'll see you there  sometime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns and starts going through the kyacks, looking fo her things. Clay frowns down at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because as you said, that's where I  belong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary's attention is on the kyacks. From where Clay stands near her he can see the trail leading down through open  country toward the meadow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said a lot of things -- some of  'em --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something o.s. catches his attention, then he pauses to l off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT - his ANGLE. Up on the ridge there is the flash sun on metal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT. Lednov, McCall and Peters ride through the tre

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay. He looks up anxiously, then turns. CAMERA ANGLE WID to include Mary and she straightens and faces him, her ba to the trail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of 'em you didn't mean but most  of 'em you did. I don't blame you  because I understand your way of  thinking and why you think that way.  You want your women on pedestals.  But they have to be born on 'em --  they can fall off but they can't  climb back up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply) I can't help how I think. You're  trained a certain way when you're a  kid and you can't change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bends down and picks up her things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're gonna catch this stage,  come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stage has speeded up and is coming fast down the road Mary looks up at Clay hurt and shocked by his sudden  sharpness. She had hoped he wouldn't let her go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't change either. Not unless  somebody wants me enough to give me  a hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts off, Mary following.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary makes one last attempt to get him to change his mind

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) I'm fool enough to believe that one  of these days somebody will. Somebody  who wants me as I am will maybe walk  into the place where I'm working and  take me out of there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe they will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waves for the stage to stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The driver sees Clay waving and pulls the horses in. The  stage moves down to the edge of the meadow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stage. It is a small one, a double-seated buckboard w one woman passenger and the driver an elderly man. On the side of the vehicle is painted: "Yosemite-Sonora Stage Li The woman, middle-aged and rather drab, looks at Mary  curiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mind giving a lady a lift into town?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mary) Climb right in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He jumps out of the stage and follows Clay, carrying Mary belongings, around back of the stage. Mary gets into the  stage beside the woman who moves over for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on back of stage. The driver opens the boot and Clay hand him Mary's belongings. He starts stowing them in the boot

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you be seeing the sheriff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Depot's right next to his office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay starts scribbling a note. In the b.g. Steve has move up beside the stage. He stands looking up at Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: featuring Mary and Steve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shyly) Goodbye, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary reaches down and takes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Goodbye, Steve. Don't fight with him  any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve's expression hardens. He glances toward the back of the stage, then at Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not his fault, just you remember  that. It's mine. Don't ask me why  because you couldn't understand now.  Some day you will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay and the driver come around the stage. Steve steps ba The driver climbs into the seat. Clay and Mary look at ea other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye. Thanks for the lift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the way, if you ever go past the  Wyatt ranch, have another talk with  Elaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Clay can speak, the driver snaps his whip and the  stage jerks away down the road. Mary doesn't look back. C in f.g., looks after it. Dust rises. It disappears around bend in the road. Clay turns and starts across the meadow Steve looks after Clay, hesitates, then follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Clay reaches the spot where the kyacks and saddles are thrown. Steve comes up to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what she asked me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care what she asked you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She told me not to fight with you  anymore. She said it wasn't your  fault, but -- I figure different...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay is looking off, hardly listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is so your fault and... and I  guess maybe when we hit the ranch...  you andme better...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply) You want to split up? --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay's eyes are narrow, peering toward:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT (Clay's ANGLE) of the shadowed slope. Something moves, indistinct, and then the sun catches a gun barrel it disappears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay and Steve as Clay turns sharply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Why wait? Go on, saddle up now  and beat it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve looks over toward the horses, stalling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half of them are mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hard) You'll get your share. Go on. I don't  want you around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turning, he crosses to where Steve's horse stands. CAMERA ANGLE WIDENS. He loads the horse back, throws a blanket a saddle on and cinches up the saddle. Steve watches, angry and hurt. Clay steps back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the two brothers. They stare at each other. Steve is on t verge of tears. Hurriedly, he swings into the saddle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances down to Clay and digs his spurs in and gallops after the stage. Clay's stern expression leaves his face. looks after the boy, smiles softly and then starts carryi the pack-saddle into the shelter of the forest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT. Steve rides along the road. He pulls his horse in, then glances back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT - Steve's ANGLE. Clay is carrying the belonging into the shelter of the forest. CAMERA PANS OVER and UP.  Momentarily a horseman is seen riding into an open space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve as he stares. Then understanding his brother's acti he jerks the reins and swings the horse around and rides  back toward the meadow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT - Steve gallops across the meadow to the corral swings off and starts unsaddling. Clay is inside the fore lighting the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay. He looks over toward Steve, then rises and hurries  toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay and Steve. Steve takes down the bars and puts the ho in the corral. Clay comes up to him as he's putting the b back up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you come back for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like I told you, half those horses  are mine. I'm makin' sure they get  to the ranch safe. So let's quit  arguing and do whatever you figure  on doin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two brothers stare at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Is that the only reason you came  back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gruff) Sure. What other reason would there  be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) I just wondered. Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT - DOWN ANGLE. Above the pines smoke rises. The  horses graze inside the corral. In the shadowy forest by creek, Clay's camp can be seen. A tarp has been stretched over the camp. Lednov moves into the right hand side of t frame and looks down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lednov stands on a rocky hill looking down in the meadow. Behind him are McCall and Peters. They are screened from meadow by the rocks. Lednov turns and starts off through rocks to circle above the camp. The two men follow. All a on foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT SHOOTING PAST Clay and along his rifle. Clay, h behind a wall of rock, is watching the trail where it com down into the meadow. Something moves on the rocky hill a and to his left. He looks up, waiting. The movement stops Clay glances around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Below Clay, Steve lies in a cut in the rocks, watching th camp. Clay motions toward the hill. Steve nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAN SHOT - FROM Clay's ANGLE. CAMERA, SHOOTING THROUGH th rifle sights, SEARCHES the forest and meadow. As a flight birds suddenly rises above a section of the forest, the C HOLDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT. Lednov, McCall and Peters have stopped, halted the sudden flight of the birds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Below is the camp. Lednov motions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Peters) Go on down and have a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scoffing) And get my head blown off! Not me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lednov looks at McCall. From his pocket, McCall takes a c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCall flips the coin, shows it to Peters. Peters shrugs starts moving cautiously down toward the camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lednov and McCall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you! Get going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCall moves off to circle around in back of where Clay a Steve wait. Lednov watches him go then, moving to the she of the rocks, waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His position commands the meadow, where the horses are  corralled, and the camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT - Clay's ANGLE. The forest is silent. Then,  momentarily, Peters is in the open. Clay brings his rifle up, trying to get him in the sights. Wheeler disappears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT. Stealthily, Peters makes his way down toward t camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLED PAST Peters. Peters, sheltered by a tree trunk, ra his rifle, then his eye catches a movement. He fires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT - PAST Clay. Clay has Peters in his sights. He  fires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peters. Peters is stretched on the needle-covered earth,  dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. CLOSE - Clay. Clay throws the empty cartridge out an another in. O.s. there is a SHOT. A bullet hits near him. Clay looks off in the direction where Lednov is waiting o the hill west of the camp. Another SHOT is heard. A bulle smacks into the rock close to Clay. It comes from McCall' position southwest of the camp. Clay ducks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT - Lednov's ANGLE. Lednov is trying to get Clay his sights. He fires as Clay is seen momentarily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT - McCall's ANGLE. McCall fires at Clay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay and Steve crawl down and away from Lednov and McCall positions. Steve grins at Clay. He is enjoying this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Stick here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moving cautiously he starts in McCall's direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. LONG SHOT. McCall, rifle ready looks down toward the base of the log where Steve now waits. A twig snaps below He sights the rifle, waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. CLOSE. Clay stands still. The forest is silent again

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. LONG SHOT. Lednov, sheltered by a tree, has his rifl trained on Clay's position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVING SHOT. Clay, walking cautiously, climbs toward McCa position. Ahead is an open area. Stooping, Clay picks up rock and draws back his arm to throw it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. LONG SHOT - ANGLED TOWARD open area below. The stone thrown by Clay, crashes in the brush across the open area McCall fires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: UP ANGLE PAST Clay. The flash of sunlight on McCall's rif attracts Clay's attention. He fires. From behind him, Ste fires. Clay runs across the open area. Steve fires again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT. McCall tries to struggle to his feet. Failing, brings his rifle up. Clay in b.g. runs to the shelter of tree. McCall fires. Clay's rifle barrel emerges from behi tree. McCall tries to drag himself to safety. Clay fires. McCall goes down on his face. From Lednov's position come the SOUND of a shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay's ANGLE. CAMERA SEARCHES Lednov's position for some  movement. There is none.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOWN ANGLE PAST Lednov. Below in the corral the horses ar hunched together. Lednov looks down, then raising his rif he brings one of the horses into the beads of the sights. is the bell mare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) Come on out, Phillips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His voice echoes again and again. Clay's answer is a shot It cuts the branches above Lednov's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lednov. He ducks lower, steadies his rifle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his voice echoing) Those horses down there -- they don't  amount to much to me. Look at the  one with the bell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLED THROUGH sights. The sights center on the bell mare

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve. He is standing recklessly trying to find Lednov in the rocks above.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay. He stares down at the horses. A shot is heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT. The bell mare rears as the bullet strikes the  bell. The horses mill around the corral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling; echoing) Next time I won't miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay. He starts forward, face set with rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (echoing) Watch the one with the white face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Recklessly Clay raises his rifle and fires three shots at Lednov's position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. FULL SHOT as Clay fires, Steve starts running down. crosses the creek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT - DOWN. Lednov sees Steve running. He swings hi rifle away from the horses and tries to get the boy in hi sights. Clay fires again. A bullet smacks into the tree.  Lednov flinches. Then again he tries to center on Steve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT. Steve runs, bending low, toward the rail fence bullet kicks up dirt near him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT - DOWN. Steve has almost reached the fence. Led fires. Steve stumbles and goes down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve. He lies still a moment, then painfully he crawls t the rails and with a great effort tries to tear the rails down. Lednov fires. The bullet whistles past. Steve pulls the fence down, crawls away from the opening. The horses, milling around the corral break through. Steve lies still face down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The meadow, ANGLED PAST Clay. The horses scatter across t meadow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay, now the hunter, moves toward Lednov's position. Led fires. Clay runs and jumps into the creek. Sheltered by t bank he makes his way up the creek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lednov. He waits, his rifle ready. O.s. a twig snaps.  Cautiously he looks ahead. There is silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: his ANGLE. A light wind runs through the great trees. Sha of light filter through the trees, making patterns on the forest floor. The light is dim, deceptive. Lednov, rifle  ready, searches for some sign of Clay. Then from another  direction comes the SOUND of movement. Lednov swings his  rifle in that direction, waits. The SOUND has stopped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here Lednov.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His voice echoes across the hills. Lednov sights along hi rifle at the direction from which the SOUND of Clay's voi came. Momentarily Clay is seen as he runs from one tree t another. Lednov fires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay. Clay cautiously edges around the base of a tree. He picks up a stick, stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His voice can be heard echoing across the hills. He tosse the stick. Lednov fires at the SOUND of the falling stick

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come and get me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As his voice echoes across the hills Clay quickly moves i the open and fires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lednov crumples forward as his echoing voice fades out. C moves over to him to stand looking down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT. Steve sits propped up against the fence rail. shirt is off and his shoulder is crudely bandaged. Clay, has been putting the bandage on, stands and takes a sack tobacco from his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rolling cigarette) How's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kind of sore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shyly) Guess maybe I'm old enough to hold  my own in a fight, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah -- but don't make a habit of  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So -- maybe I'm old enough to tell  you how to run your life?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stares down at him,  then) I guess so -- but don't make a habit  of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then, I know it takes three --  four weeks for you to come round to  admit when you're wrong... But by  that time she's liable to be in  China...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay looks at him for a moment, not angry, but not admitt he's wrong yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT - featuring hotel and doctor's office. The sher posse, the bodies of Lednov, McCall and Wheeler slung acr the backs of horses, and Clay's remuda, trot down the str People come out of the hotel to watch the cavalcade pass. Clay and Steve are not with the posse. Clay's horse is  tethered in front of the doctor's office which is next do to the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT - ANGLED THROUGH window. Clay, back to camera, holding a kerosine lamp. The doctor, a lanky, middle-aged man, is working over Steve, who is stretched out on a tab

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT. Shelves filled with bottles line the room, for the doctor is also the druggist. There is a glass cabinet which are the doctor's instruments. The room is cluttered The lamp, held by Clay, throws a circle of pale light dow on Steve. The doctor is working on Steve's shoulder and a

dialogues.speaker: UP ANGLE
dialogues.text: featuring Clay. Clay suddenly averts his glance and wince as the doctor probes the wound in Steve's arm. Steve groa The lamp wavers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply) Hold her steady. I'm not hurting  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you're not, but I'll sure be  glad when you stop pokin' me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Footsteps are HEARD approaching. Clay tries to steady his shaking hand. He is focusing his attention on a far wall. woman's hand comes in the scene and takes the lamp from h He reacts. CAMERA PULLS BACK to reveal Mary, who has move in beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve. He smiles up at Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLES PAST doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it very bad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grumbling) Course not. A scratch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He suddenly realizes that a strange woman is in the room reacts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doin' here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holding the lamp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then hold it a little lower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary lowers the lamp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay and Mary. UP ANGLE PAST lamp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for taking over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Thanks for loading me on the stage.  I know now why you did it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like I said, women get in the way  sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tried to get rid of me, too, Miss  Wells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep still, will you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He straightens into the shot. CAMERA PULLS BACK TO MED. S Steve is now bandaged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put him over there on the cot.  Goodnight... He'll be all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Clay lifts Steve to the cot the doctor exits. Mary wat Clay cover Steve. Then she goes to the door leading to th street, stops with her hand on the knob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodnight, Miss Wells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking back) If you need me, I'll be --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay straightens and turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the other side of the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens the door and starts out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT. Mary starts to close the door behind her. Clay forces it open. Clay comes out. Mary starts toward the st

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary stops at the edge of the porch. Clay comes up beside her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary waits, looking up at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That job you were talkin' about, did  you get it yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (haltingly) Because... well, you said you wanted  a man to think enough of you to walk  in the place you were working and  take you out of there... tonight I  was sort of tied up with Steve...  but tomorrow I figured on doing just  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) I haven't got the job yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if you want to wait until tomorrow --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For answer, Clay takes her in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLED PAST Steve on cot. In the b.g. through the open  doorway, Clay and Mary kiss. Steve watches a moment, then turns his head toward camera. He smiles and closes his ey

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO SHOT - Mary and Clay. They break from the kiss. Clay  looks down at Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Is there any place in town a man  could buy some gingham?
